movie_review_blurb: Kids will enjoy it, but young adults and adults will get more laughs out of it.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.

RZA's directorial debut, The Man With The Iron Fists, shows a lot of love for the kung fu classics and martial arts movies which inspired it, but it doesn't quite have that feel of exhilaration that they have.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The Bay doesn't break any new ground, but it shows Barry Levinson using the horror genre to his advantage.
Universal Soldier: Day of Reckoning comes off feeling like the Alien 3 of the franchise, as it becomes, at times, far too nihilistic to be enjoyed.

The Guilt Trip is something of a mixed bag. On one hand it has the combined talents of Seth Rogen and Barbara Streisand, who work terrifically off of one another, and on the other it's not that different from other road movies we have seen.
Thanks to a wonderful cast and Crystal's good intentions, Parental Guidance is a much better movie than one might expect it to be.
Parker turns out to be a big letdown as it brings nothing new to the crime thriller genre, and it is not likely to stay with you long after the credits have finished.
Safe Haven is nothing more than a rip-off of Sleeping With The Enemy, and it strands its strong cast in a story that is manipulative, convoluted and unintentionally hilarious.
Thanks to a game cast, taut action scenes and a surprising dose of raw emotion, Alex Cross finally gets the movie that he deserves.
Upside Down dazzles us on a visual level but bores us with a Romeo & Juliet-like story of two lovers from opposing worlds.
What Maisie Knew is a fascinating movie about what goes on inside the mind of a child when their parents divorce.
Despite strong performances from Keanu Reeves, Bojana Novakovic and Adelaide Clemens, Generation Um... doesn't give us enough of a story to keep us fully invested throughout its running time.

Stories We Tell starts out as a simple investigation into the life of a mother that director Sarah Polley barely knew and slowly turns into a documentary that is as good as any movie you will see this year.
Epic is very pleasing on a visual level, but its story of good versus evil is no different than the ones we grew up reading about and watching.
Storm Surfers 3D is a thrilling ride into the world of surfing. If you can find it playing at a theatre near you, I highly recommend checking it out, whether you're into the sport or not.
21 and Over desperately wants to be The Hangover and Superbad for a new generation of moviegoers, but it is nowhere as funny or as memorable as any of those movies.
Hickenlooper's approach to the subject plus a great performance by Kevin Spacey make Casino Jack an enjoyable comedy and thought provoking social commentary.
A big screen B-movie with a convoluted plot and limited scope - inundating viewers with melodrama instead of the alien invasion apocalypse occurring outside.
127 Hours is an inspiring dramatic thriller with creative direction by Danny Boyle and a commanding performance from James Franco.
Phillips convolutes the adventure with a bizarre mix of unrealized emotional complexity and over-the-top gross-out humor but most viewers will still enjoy the loony ride.
For every moment of raw self-destruction there is an equally charming resolution.
Another thin Saw franchise installment. Fans of the series will find plenty of the same horrors to enjoy but the film furthers the series' decline into mediocrity.
A terrific, albeit dreary, character drama that directly addresses one of humanity's most enduring mysteries.
Not the feel-good film of the year, but Greenberg is a powerful account of how a few lost souls can find meaning and direction in life.
Reynolds and Cortés deserve credit for their ambition and Buried is a tense but enjoyable experience for anyone interested in the core 'buried alive' concept.
Another Resident Evil zombie film with no brains but plenty of over-the-top action should still sate the appetite of certain viewers.
It's unlikely that moviegoers will be quite as taken by the experience this time.
For viewers who have grown tired of the countless stock horror films in the genre, Sinister should provide an especially engaging and refreshingly spooky experience.
Moviegoers who can handle philosophical musings accompanied by exploding heads will find that McDonagh has delivered another sharp and entertaining film.
Whether you attend the Paranormal Activity movies for the scares or the story, part 4 is a major step down.
Despite the obvious movie structure that gets forced onto historical events, The King's Speech is a terrific film with great performances and an inspiring story.
Places too much time in the hands of disposable characters - so that it is neither a brainless slasher flick nor an immersive character piece based in a serial massacre.
Mixed in with flat characters and tense action is an incredible 3D visual component - which is where Cameron's involvement in the project is most apparent.
Fun performances from Routh and Huntington can't make up for an extremely convoluted and mostly soulless story -- even when there's a giant zombie running around.
A serviceable comedy outing with a number of surprisingly funny moments, along with a number of shocking but dumb-witted set-ups.
Delivers on the promise of an exciting genre mash-up but, even with a talented cast and revered team of writers, fails to weave a fulfilling story.
Rides the entertaining pitch for the entire runtime -- without attempting to offer some kind of deeper insight or social commentary.
Despite an over-long and underwhelming build-up, the final hour of Dark of the Moon is an all-out action fest with some of the coolest visuals ever put to film.
Despite a more interesting plot, Cars 2 still leans on a number of problems established in the first film -- specifically leading men, Lightning McQueen and Mater.
Malick may have pushed the envelope a bit too far, losing the ability to see the forest for the trees - even in a film as beautiful and surreal as The Tree of Life
There is fun to be had and it's exciting (for a moment) to see Captain Jack Sparrow on the big screen again but the overall production suffers from franchise burnout.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A unique and thoughtful project that showcases a charming, as well as unconventional, character journey -- and one of Gibson's best roles to date.
Priest is a lousy action movie with boring characters, a convoluted plot, and, most unforgivable, very little compelling action.
Silent Hill: Revelation 3D is a mixed bag of creepy and downright captivating visual set-pieces coupled with melodramatic dialogue and an overly-complicated storyline.
The series has found new traction in the heist format -- resulting in a fun and immensely entertaining ride.
Returning horror fans should enjoy Scream 4. The series remains smartly unapologetic in toying with meta-references and horror-film expectations.
Slapstick dramedy fans will likely get some laughs out of the Arthur remake but the film is stuck in the same naïve adolescence as its titular character.
In spite of an over-complicated premise, Source Code succeeds in offering an above-average thriller -- with interesting sci-fi ideas for genre buffs to debate.
Snyder was aiming for more than an action-packed popcorn flick -- making it hard to ignore that the filmmaker, much like Babydoll, temporarily lost his footing in reality.
Meditations on identity make Rango unique, and somewhat special, in the current animated film landscape.
An exciting film that moviegoers will enjoy - even if they leave with a somewhat ambiguous understanding of the story that was unfolding outside of Neeson's character.
The Bay is two-thirds of a captivating found footage outbreak movie that's crushed under the weight of lofty ambition before completing its runtime.
In spite of some exceptionally indulgent choices by the fan-favorite director, Django Unchained is another sharp and enjoyable Tarantino effort.
Is Skyfall the best Bond film yet? No. Is it a smart and engaging Bond film? Absolutely.
The Host is a passable film that could entertain a slim segment of viewers that were turned-off by Twilight - while fully catering to the Twihard crowd.
The tasteful Jurassic Park 3D conversion injects new wonder and excitement into one of the most captivating adventure movies ever made.
Scary Movie 5 is a dumbed down and hollow version of the franchise formula - resulting in an idiotic (and unamusing) attempt at parody that is tedious not fun.
Certain storylines and characters are more nuanced than others but, overall, 42 is a multi-faceted blend of exciting baseball scenes and captivating human drama.
'Oblivion' tells a captivating future story with rich visuals and an intriguing leading man.
Pain & Gain isn't a bad movie but it is a flat adaptation - only telling the story of the Sun Gym Gang without adding worthwhile insight (or many laughs).
Iron Man 3 is not the best Marvel Studios movie, but it provides plenty of fun and excitement for both Iron Man die-hards and newly acquired Avengers fans.
Another bold and exciting voyage for the Starship Enterprise - one that will likely wow most moviegoers (even if it irks a few die-hard Trekkies).
Fast & Furious 6 is a little unwieldy, saddled with a lot of added baggage, but it's still an extremely entertaining ride.
After Earth is an extremely uneven and flawed film, but for moviegoers who are intrigued by the initial premise, it's not the throwaway disaster that some might claim.
The Internship is harmless but fails to deliver laughs worthy of "Googliness." Instead, it's more akin to Yahoo! - a functional Plan B when nothing better is available.
The Bling Ring is a stylish commentary on fame-obsessed teen culture, even if the movie dismisses the real-life perpetrators as little more than naive punks.
World War Z transforms from an engaging glimpse at post-apocalyptic human endurance into a brainless shell that is as absentminded as its undead subject matter.
A brainless but competent (read: not essential) blockbuster thriller that is likely to satisfy filmgoers who were intrigued by the trailers and one-man-army premise.
Certain audience members will enjoy this Lone Ranger but it's style over substance that fails to elevate the series in any meaningful (or particularly exciting) way.
Olympus Has Fallen could underwhelm moviegoers expecting one of Fuqua's riveting character dramas but should provide action fans with plenty of explosions and machismo.
Wreck-It-Ralph enjoys a smart ratio of accessible character drama and goofy gaming gags - resulting in an exceptionally entertaining, and heartfelt, animated adventure.
The Incredible Burt Wonderstone is all style and no substance - a stunt illusion with no magic.
Despite a predictable story and some awkward visuals, Giant Slayer is surprisingly entertaining - thanks to a hefty dose of well-timed humor and energetic performances.
Unintentionally humorous exchanges and awkward visuals undercut the quality of the filmmaking - but the final movie delivers a solid conclusion for its intended audience.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The overarching message will be hard to translate for non-believing adults, but the film still offers a worthwhile dose of harmless fun and worthwhile heart.
The Collection is not going to win over gore film skeptics - and that's not necessarily a bad thing. It's an unapologetic celebration of splatter cinema.
A few extemporaneous Lord of the Rings elements distract from The Hobbit storyline but Jackson has presented a captivating and exciting return to Middle-earth.
Jack Reacher is a frame for Cruise to flex his (aging) action muscles but that doesn't mean the film fails to satisfy with plenty of excitement, charm, and head-stomping.
The Guilt Trip delivers an average but unremarkable comedy offering with enough heart to make up for some missed laughs.
Filmgoers who enjoyed the cartoon (or comic strips) as a kid will very likely be left with the taste of sour Smurfberries.
Texas Chainsaw 3D fails on both fronts - as a quality horror experience and a competent evolution of the Leatherface character.
A crowd-pleasing tale of cops and mobsters but bungled characterization and underwhelming style-over-substance prevents Gangster Squad from being a crime genre classic.
The Last Stand is a fun throwback to the days of formulaic but immensely entertaining Schwarzenegger-led films.
Despite aiming for a deeper character story, Hansel & Gretel: Witch Hunters only succeeds as mindless and bloody entertainment - thin as its fairy tale source material.
Warm Bodies moves at a steady pace and includes enough charming moments to keep the film alive (even if the romance is just undead).
Side Effects isn't just a clever film, there's beauty in its execution.
For a film about love and witches, Beautiful Creatures is a passionless experience, surprisingly devoid of actual movie magic.
Snitch is not the action movie that some viewers might have been expecting but that's not a bad thing - it delivers a surprisingly engaging character drama instead.
There are some underdeveloped ideas, but the central story - the making of a great man - invokes the "spirit" of Victor Fleming's classic for an entertaining return to Oz.
It's easy to recommend The Change-Up for its over-the-top laughs and a pair of solid leads that succeed in offering a raunchy twist on a familiar formula.
Tom and Brendan are enough to offer a satisfying payoff - even if minor characters are left flailing in their wake.
Final Destination 5 benefits from smart 3D, but even in 2D, the set-pieces will satisfy -- presenting some of the most outrageous kill sequences in franchise history.
Discerning viewers will find problems with a few of the film's twists and turns, but moment to moment, there's still plenty of fun to be had with the Men in Black.
Provides good chuckles and heartfelt drama - paired with an equal amount of familiar gags and flat story ideas.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Not a colossal failure but an indicator that Burton and Depp could stand to step outside their collective me + you = cinematic magic mindsets.
A bizarre mishmash of historical elements and subpar on-screen drama capped off with an underwhelming but serviceable performance from John Cusack
It's a bit over-stuffed, but the narrative does come full-circle and successfully balances charming comedy gags grounded in a memorable and contemporary love story.
Lockout succeeds as a result of Pearce - who delivers an enjoyable, albeit snide, performance as a government agent turned one-man-army.
A surprisingly entertaining effort that works because it strikes a smart balance - embracing as well as rejecting viewer expectations and knowledge of the horror genre.
Titanic 3D lacks creative synergy that could have been explored had the film been shot with 3D in mind but its easily the best example of post-conversion to date.
Mirror Mirror features over-indulgent story moments and, at times, hammy performances but still delivers a mostly fun riff on the Snow White story.
Some plot threads are underserved but The Hunger Games is a fascinating and disturbing character drama that successfully captures the core themes of the book.
An exploration of troubled teenagers as well as counter-cultural angst that, because of its commitment to the ugly side of truth, is rife with honesty and captivating drama.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An off-putting juxtaposition of heartfelt character moments and lowbrow poop jokes prevent Hotel Transylvania from ever being especially heartfelt or funny.
21 Jump Street gets the remake job done with tongue-in-cheek style & plenty of outrageous moments.
An enjoyable indie dramedy with a number of engaging moments and a solid performance from Jason Segel but not nearly as deep as the ideals that fuel Jeff's character.
Moviegoers looking for a unique horror-thriller experience, who find the "real time" premise intriguing, are likely to enjoy Silent House in spite of its flaws.
Chernobyl Diaries is a mismatched effort that was working with some intriguing core elements -- undermined by worn-out recreations of familiar horror set-ups.
Unlike prior 'house party' movies, Project X says nothing meaningful about its subject matter and, instead, paints teens as unlikeable and reckless automatons.
Prometheus is a welcome return to form for Ridley Scott -- delivering a fascinating sci-fi storyline, gorgeous 3D visuals, and competent filmmaking choices.
As a tongue-in-cheek action mashup, Grahame-Smith and Bekmambetov have, for the most part, delivered an entertaining (albeit campy) historical retelling.
Dredd is an extremely enjoyable action ride and, in spite of a limited story, provides the infamous Judge with a surprisingly engaging film adaptation.
Trouble with the Curve is exactly what potential viewers probably expect - a dependable, albeit overly familiar, character story
Resident Evil: Retribution is style-over-substance in every possible definition of the concept.
Finding Nemo 3D is a quality post-conversion experience that successfully enhances the 2003 film's original standout visuals.
Despite an exposition-heavy outer layer, The Words delivers on 2/3 threads that it presents and offers a somewhat evocative meditation on truth.
The Possession fails to differentiate itself from standard exorcism stories and movie experiences - even if it is 'Based on True Events.'
Lawless may not entirely live up to the sum of all its celebrated parts but it succeeds in telling a riveting 'true life' historical drama.
Eye-popping practical bike work should provide interested viewers with a middle-of-the-road rush that's a bit short of 'premium.'
'The Bourne Legacy' is by no means a bad film. Unfortunately, it just has trouble living up to the real world Jason Bourne 'legacy.'
Enough visual spectacle to make viewers wish they had three eyeballs but thin characters and a convoluted story ultimately undermine Wiseman's successes.
The Watch is a lazy production at nearly every level. Expect these aliens to have better luck in a couple years - when they invade basic cable.
Savages is a mix of challenging story beats & multifaceted character moments -- paired with an equal number of predictable twists & flat cliched personalities.
Certain elements of the plot are uneven but a number of captivating performances and an intriguing premise elevate People Like Us above standard drama fare.
Ted presents plenty of fresh laughs and, from time to time, heart/stuffing-warming character moments.
While it doesn't break a lot of new ground, Brave is a beautiful and competent entry in Disney's robust fairytale film pedigree.
Rock of Ages panders to its base without putting in the extra effort to standout as not just a competent musical but a must-see film experience for all audiences.
Despite thin human drama, and one note supporting characters, Rise of the Planet of the Apes is a surprisingly sincere story that elevates the franchise canon.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Act of Valor is a love letter to servicemen but it's also a disjointed mishmash of slick combat sequences paired with awkward performances and a generic storyline.
Anyone hoping the 3D would make-up for the film's many shortcomings, will probably continue to feel cheated by the first Star Wars prequel.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: It's unlikely that Brewer's Footloose will persuade many remake skeptics but the film does deliver surprisingly enjoyable character drama and exciting choreography.
Despite a competent performance from Butler, Machine Gun Preacher tackles way too much material to present a cohesive onscreen telling of the Sam Childers story.
Real Steel offers plenty of fun and engaging moments -- of both the human character drama and giant CGI robot battle variety.
50/50 is a thoughtful and challenging story, grounded in real world characters, that also manages rewarding and cathartic laughs.
Lautner fans will enjoy five separate occasions where the star takes off his shirt but, for fans of worthwhile trips to the theater, Abduction is hard to recommend.
A cartoony and messy narrative that is mostly style over substance.
Great performances, exciting moments, and creative cinematography make Moneyball a home run for both baseball and movie fans.
Straw Dogs does little more than rely on graphic violence as well as outdated stereotypes to keep the tension high.
Fans of RED will enjoy seeing their favorite characters back on the big screen, but for less-devoted viewers RED 2 is only an average action-comedy experience.
Tucker and Dale vs Evil is deliciously fun satire -- and, once all the blood has been spilt, offers an interesting riff on the line between hero and horror villain.
An artistic celebration of the extremes in life but, without anything in between, most everyone is reduced to an unrelatable outline.
It's impossible to recommend Apollo 18 to anyone but the most staunch found-footage fans. The film fails every requirement of a tense and enjoyable time at the theater.
Audiences will see a couple of intended surprises coming but the lack of surprise doesn't detract from how these moments affect the characters and serve the larger story.
Colombiana is caught somewhere in the middle of an engaging character drama and a brainless action extravaganza.
Conan the Barbarian is a hollow beat 'em up with shallow characters and, worst of all, below average action.
Paranormal Activity 3 doesn't reinvent the series' wheel but it definitely refines an already effective format.
It's not the most realistic spy film or the most tear-enducing romance; however, This Means War works as a middle-of-the-road guilty pleasure.
A subtle, yet challenging, character drama with stand-out performances and some truly beautiful camerawork.
Intriguing performances help The Rum Diary successfully capture the spirit of the source material -- even if the result is a scattered piece of filmmaking.
Chronicle isn't just a unique found-footage movie or superior superhero film, it's a truly enjoyable blend of the best each genre has to offer.
A noteworthy performance from Liam Neeson keeps the character moments engaging and the man vs. nature scenarios offer a number of memorable sequences.
With an inspiring source story, talented actors, and one of the most profitable production companies backing the film, it's genuinely hard to imagine where it all went wrong.
Haywires shortcomings don't detract from the minute to minute onscreen ride - featuring Carano's fresh (and uncompromising) action work.
An exposition-heavy opening act and an abrupt lack of closure may leave moviegoers feeling underserved by The Devil Inside's few genuinely scary moments.
A muddled focus keeps We Bought a Zoo from being a guaranteed hit with kids or a captivating adult drama but there are enough compelling moments to make it worthwhile.
A compelling ride for die-hard fans of the book series, dramatic thriller enthusiasts, as well as anyone who enjoys Fincher's darker works.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Brad Bird takes the series up a notch with enjoyable character dynamics and a straightforward but still intriguing story featuring plenty of unique action set pieces.
Anyone expecting The Sitter to be an especially memorable trip to the theater may just want to give their own babysitter the night off and stay home with the kids.
Steve McQueen delivers an experience that simultaneously offers beautiful filmmaking and a welcome punch to the gut.
A Muppet film that not only lives up to the franchise legacy and, for some, might just end up being one of their all-time favorite adventures with Kermit and the gang.
Breaking Dawn - Part 1 transfers pivotal events from the source material to the screen but fails to translate those events into a competent two-hour movie experience.
Tarsem Singh's imaginative visuals are the main draw of Immortals - which is subsequently held together by a mostly adequate story of gods, titans, and humanity.
J. Edgar provides an intriguing look at one of America's icons but Eastwood fails to deliver a cohesive narrative or enough compelling insight into his subject.
Falls short of being a holiday classic or an enjoyable 3D experience - meaning, in the end, it's little more than another Harold and Kumar film.
Puss offers strong CGI charisma, and with a tighter narrative focus than Shrek, it's safe to say that DreamWorks has another franchise-worthy golden goose.
Several story and comedy beats are derivative, but scenes of thoughtful insight are frequent enough for The To Do List to offer more than just brainless laughs.
War Horse offers a number of memorable moments both tragic and profound.
In spite of some predictable story beats, and stock buddy cop setups, 2 Guns offers plenty of pleasing moments - thanks to a fun pair of performances from its leads.
Despite a solid premise and talented supporting cast, Pixels is another shallow addition to Adam Sandler's product line.
All the pieces were in place for a refreshing entry in the superhero genre, but Fantastic Four completely unravels at the halfway point.
The Gift is a haunting character drama that successfully incorporates elements of the thriller and psychological horror genres.
Though viewers will find familiar story beats and characters in The Man from U.N.C.L.E., Ritchie succeeds in creating a fun love-letter to 1960s spy fandom.
The Boy is a very slow burn, one that successfully works to the narrative at hand, but isn't particularly enjoyable to watch.
Despite a lot of shortcomings and undercooked elements, The Transporter Refueled is a mildly entertaining action film.
Black Mass is an intriguing blend of classic gangster movie drama under the umbrella of an intimate Bulger biopic.
Everest is a sobering character story packed with bravery, horror, and humility - as well as thrilling tension.
The Scorch Trials maintains the semi-successful bar of intriguing movie escapism set by The Maze Runner.
Hotel Transylvania 2 offers cute but brainless escapism for young moviegoers - as well as parents looking to distract their children for a few hours.
The Martian hits a powerful sweet spot: blending tense action, captivating science, and beautiful 3D cinematography into an emotional character story.
Steve Jobs is a quality portrait of Apple's co-founder, with a gripping turn from Fassbender - even if the film plays fast and loose with history
In spite of connections to the ongoing series saga, Paranormal Activity: The Ghost Dimension could easily be mistaken for an Asylum B-movie knockoff.
Dazzling visuals and fun supernatural brawls can't save The Last Witch Hunter from a cliché plot and uneven Vin Diesel performance.
An entertaining and earnest chronicle of the 33 with solid performances - one that is undercut by otherwise standard docudrama throughout.
Trainwreck is an honest film that defies gender stereotypes; though, more often than not, it still adheres to familiar romantic comedy tropes.
The Night Before manages to be both an irreverent and sincere Christmas movie, sure to be a holiday favorite (albeit a zany one) for years to come.
Self/less is an average science-fiction drama that pulls heavily from prior filmic explorations of immortality - and passes familiar plot beats off as fresh ideas.
Me and Earl and the Dying Girl is a must-see for moviegoers who aren't afraid to find joy and self-reflection in the story of a dying girl.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Even though Project Almanac does not reinvent the found footage format, the movie still manages to tell a gripping (and stylish) time travel story.
Smart genre riffs and hyper-stylized action, Kingsman: The Secret Service manages to provide a clever twist on the spy movie format.
The Duff makes timely points about self-love, body image, and modern relationships but falls short of becoming a teen drama classic.
Despite its 'never lose focus' catchphrase, unnecessary tangents and underwhelming reveals make Focus a somewhat unfocused, though still enjoyable, viewing experience.
Chappie succeeds in Blomkamp's goal: exploring a heightened version of childhood development told through the lens of gritty science-fiction and gangster stereotypes.
Cinderella plays it overly-safe in transitioning from cartoon-to-live-action but is sure to entertain Disney's go-to juice box crowd.
Insurgent falls short of hitting the bar set by superior YA film adaptations but is a step in the right direction for the Divergent series.
Home is a colorful and entertaining CGI adventure, but weighed down by an uneven and shallow story, falls short of animated greatness.
Ex Machina is memorable and downright challenging, full of sharp performances that blur the lines between humanity and programming.
It misses the bar of classic movie greatness but Avengers: Age of Ultron is one of the most exciting and entertaining Marvel entries.
Pitch Perfect 2 will sate its target audience - though that audience may have trouble sharing the movie with casual comedy lovers.
Poltergeist is a forgettable diversion - one that will only satisfy casual viewers looking for a mildly eerie (and sometimes humorous) ghost story.
It may be big, loud, and pretty dumb, but San Andreas is a fun (albeit fleeting) piece of summer blockbuster escapism.
A streamlined story and menacing villain make-up for Insidious: Chapter 3 's imperfections - an eerie, albeit forgettable, horror movie.
Inside Out is an important reflection on the power of emotion - and proof that Pixar is still king of imaginative CG animated storytelling.
Terminator Genisys is a good entry point for new viewers, with worthwhile setup for future installments, but falls short in evolving core elements of the series.
It isn't the smartest or most exciting thriller that viewers will have seen but, thanks to a quality cast and a fresh setup, Black Sea is still an entertaining watch.
The Danish Girl is a beautiful film with brave performances - though Hooper often struggles to translate Lili Elbe's life into memorable movie drama.
Bigger set pieces do not make for a better Point Break, and Core fails to improve upon the original film in any meaningful way.
Ghostbusters won't win-over pre-release haters but offers enough laughs and slick special effects to satisfy series fans and casual filmgoers alike.
Suicide Squad is a lively comic book movie - albeit one that is undermined by plot holes and uneven execution of action, character, and comedy.
Kubo and the Two Strings is Laika's most poignant, entertaining, and beautiful film yet - and one of the best movies, animated or not, of 2016
Don't Breathe cuts a fresh path, providing thrill-seeking moviegoers and horror die-hards with an inventive as well as terrifying movie experience.
Blair Witch (2016) is what The Blair Witch Project would be if the original had been made today - which is both a compliment and a concession.
The Magnificent Seven (2016) isn't going to eclipse its predecessors but it is, nonetheless, an immensely entertaining and heartfelt action-western experience.
Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children should provide moviegoers with an entertaining and emotional ride as well as nightmarish visuals to savor.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Jack Reacher: Never Go Back does not offer enough high-octane action or clever mystery to stand out from the glut of so-so crime movies.
Doctor Strange manages to expand the Marvel Cinematic Universe while also telling a satisfying story in its own isolated corner.
Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them is a solid Harry Potter series movie but often prioritizes setup over memorable drama or spellbinding action.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A well-crafted and thoughtful story drives Rogue One - in a sandbox that provides a perfect blend of modern action and classic Star Wars style.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Assassin's Creed is a step in the right direction for video game movies but slick action and beautiful visuals are undercut by a hollow hero story.
A Monster Calls is a beautiful and inspirational depiction of a young person's battle with grief - but that doesn't mean it's for every young person.
Live by Night is a dense and disorganized movie adaptation in which Ben Affleck covers too much ground for any one story or character to succeed.
Forgiving viewers may find enjoyment in R.I.P.D. but the film is so choppy and half-baked that living, thinking, moviegoers should let this one rest in peace.
Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates hits the basic mandates of R-rated comedy but falls flat in its effort to be as insightful as it is funny.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: As a big screen viewing experience based on one of America's most evocative myths, In the Heart of the Sea is a surprisingly forgettable adaptation.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Independence Day: Resurgence is B-movie CGI disaster mayhem that is elevated, only slightly, by the few fan-favorite characters who return.
Warcraft lays an enticing foundation for future installments in the fantasy-adventure series - at the expense of its current cast and story.
Concussion isn't a great biopic but it tells a great story - thanks to stirring subject matter and a quality performance from Will Smith.
As a realization of Tarantino's vision, The Hateful Eight is one of 2015's best movies - and a standout in the director's filmography.
The Forest struggles to transform its spooky premise and haunting setting into memorable or unique on-screen movie scares.
Kung Fu Panda 3 is a well-meaning piece of escapism for kids - one that shows signs of wear in the larger computer-animated kung fu franchise.
Pride and Prejudice and Zombies is unwieldy horror-comedy - delivering an amusing but gimmicky blend of Regency-era romance and zombie mythology.
Deadpool, much like its source material, is an irreverent, bloody, and riotous twist on the superhero genre - a must-see comic book movie experience.
Race finishes in the middle of the biopic genre pack - a bronze medal winner that honors Jesse Owens but falls short of cinematic greatness.
Eddie the Eagle is a light-hearted and thoroughly inspiring underdog tale - with lovable performances from Hugh Jackman and Taron Egerton.
Zootopia is filled with lovable characters and a heartfelt message for kids - along with a layered subtext for adults that is both timely and moving.
10 Cloverfield Lane has little in common with Cloverfield but is, nevertheless, a clever, thrilling, and downright fun movie experience.
Batman V Superman is DC's Iron Man 2 - an okay movie that prioritizes shared universe setup over developing a coherent story and layered characters.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Jungle Book is magnificent - honoring its literary and animated roots with thrilling action, groundbreaking effects, and heart-warming drama.
Every single piece of The Huntsman: Winter's War underwhelms - resulting in a strained prequel/sequel/spin-off fairytale with very little magic.
Stoller manages to justify his sequel but Sorority Rising's parade of R-rated gags aren't enough to hit the same highs (or longevity) as Neighbors.
X-Men: Apocalypse is a decent follow-up to Days of Future Past - albeit one that will service longtime series fans more than casual filmgoers.
Finding Dory isn't just a worthy sequel to Nemo, it also succeeds on its own - as a rousing tale of love and overcoming adversity.
Taken 3 takes the franchise past the point of absurdity - purely for the sake of selling a third series installment.
Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows is a faithful adaptation of the fan-favorite 1987 animated series - for better and for worse.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Woman in Black 2: Angel of Death is yet another example that not all successful horror movies have what it takes to become successful horror franchises.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A thoughtful, evocative, and beautifully shot look at Doctor Who's early days (for fans) that also delivers as an intriguing TV production docudrama (for non-fans).
movie_title: An Adventure in Space and Time (2013)

movie_review_blurb: For anyone who has seen the original Oldboy, Spike Lee's american remake will come across as a watered-down photocopy in nearly every way (save strong performances).
Another humorous and enthralling (read: downright entertaining) adventure in Middle-earth with rich characters, sharp visuals, and an epic storyline.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Anchorman 2 is a fun but routine followup - one that could be disappointing to viewers expecting Ferrell to deliver a superior (or at least equivalent) quality sequel.
In a story about going into the unknown, Stiller succeeds at delivering a film that, as Walter's online dating guru put its, is both 'noteworthy and mentionable.'
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The Marked Ones is a mixed bag that improves upon the narrative of the last two movies, ups the action quotient, but fails to deliver where it really counts - scares.
It's not for everyone, but Lone Survivor is a moving (and disturbing) look at Operation Red Wings - and a thoughtful glimpse at the men that gave their lives for it.
Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit falls short of realizing the character's full franchise potential - resulting in a good but not particularly groundbreaking spy movie effort.
Style over substance, I, Frankenstein establishes an interesting sandbox - one that, given a stronger story and more developed characters, might be worth revisiting.
It doesn't break new ground in examining modern relationships but a few grains of truth will be insightful and funny to the film's self-described 'selfish generation.'
An entertaining but extremely uneven film that might satisfy historical drama fans but falls very short of realizing the full potential in its gripping premise.
It might have not been 'necessary' but Josè Padilha's RoboCop reboot still offers an intriguing take on the character.
A clumsy character drama that turns one of history's most interesting and heart-breaking natural disasters into a tiresome and unmoving cinematic experience.
Like the real Battle of Artemisium, which often takes a backseat to the Battle of Thermopylae, Rise of an Empire cannot step out of 300's lofty shadow.
A no-brainer for Veronica Mars fans, but for viewers that have never seen the TV show, the movie will be (slightly) confusing and offer only average mystery drama in return.
Delivery Man's competent mix of humor and drama offers a mostly fun and even heartfelt movie experience - one that is neither laugh-out-loud or particularly insightful.
It's not particularly smart or original, but car lovers and films fans that are willing to switch off their brains should find Need for Speed offers an amusing ride.
Despite heart-warming drama and solid performances from its leads, The Book Thief fails to develop and fully realize many core relationships and thematic ideas.
Despite a few problems, Thor: The Dark World builds on the Thor (and Avengers) to offer a bigger and more exciting adventure for Marvel's God of Thunder.
Young movie fans will likely find enjoyment in Percy Jackson: Sea of Monsters but the film is a step down for the franchise in nearly every single way imaginable.
The Wedding Ringer is a mixed, but overall enjoyable, dramedy - one that includes a number of laugh-out-loud scenes couched in an often clumsy story.
Not the funniest or most thoughtful comedy but We're the Millers should provide interested viewers with a number of memorable scenes - both humorous and oddly sweet.
A passionate attempt, Jobs ultimately lacks the polish and 'greatness' that Steve Jobs routinely aimed to deliver in his own products.
The World's End isn't as unique as Pegg and Wright's prior 'Cornetto' entries but it's still a solid film that should satisfy returning series fans and comedy lovers.
Eric Bana and Rebecca Hall provide solid performances but a muddled story makes Closed Circuit a political, but not very thrilling, political thriller.
Riddick will have no problem pleasing longtime fans of the series while also delivering an accessible and entertaining sci-fi action experience for casual moviegoers.
Thriller and drama enthusiasts should find plenty of powerful performances and rich story material to make Prisoners an exhilarating and penetrating theater experience.
Not as fresh as the original but offers more than just re-heated leftovers - with an entertaining adventure that justifies a second helping of Flint Lockwood and friends.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Solid performances from Brühl and Hemsworth ground this exciting sports story with a likable mix of charisma, reverence, and speed.
Runner Runner is elevated by solid performances but, for a story about gambling and striving for greatness, the film (ironically) takes very few risks.
In spite of good intentions, A.C.O.D. fails to capitalize on its compelling 'Adult Children of Divorce' platform to present viewers with equally captivating insights.
While it might not have been necessary, the Carrie remake is still an adept, entertaining, and at times downright haunting, piece of filmmaking.
The story is thin but Bad Grandpa successfully freshens the Jackass format and will, without question, keep fans of the series laughing (and cringing) the entire time.
The cast of Last Vegas makes the film more than just a Hangover retread with older actors - but not a whole lot more.
About Time is a solid tale about love, loss, and family with great performances - that leans on a compelling but sometimes problematic time-travel premise.
Kids and Muppet fans will find plenty to enjoy but nearly every element of the film fails to capture the heart and larger social relevance featured in 2011's The Muppets.
Clever filmmaking choices and a phenomenal pair of star performances make Captain Phillips an exciting and evocative retelling of the MV Maersk Alabama hijacking.
A timely narrative, deep exploration of fan-favorite characters, and unforgettable action set pieces make Captain America: The Winter Soldier one of Marvel's best.
The Giver is a surprisingly generic addition to the young adult film genre - especially for a story that champions individuality and self-expression.
Sin City: A Dame to Kill For is a jumbled but still enjoyable followup that, for most moviegoers, arrived on the scene too late.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: In a genre where smarts and thrills are pivotal, The November Man delivers only routine (and uninspired) spy drama.
The Maze Runner leans heavily on its premise, to the detriment of individual characters, but still succeeds as one of Hollywood's better young adult adaptations.
Hector and the Search for Happiness includes laughs and relatable drama but struggles to find balance between engaging journeys and thought-provoking destinations.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Gone Girl is a layered film experience that can be appreciated on multiple levels - with an intriguing central mystery, rounded characters, and sharp social commentary.
The Judge is a very familiar tale of a man that finds humility in a return to his hometown - albeit one with a few genuinely powerful moments of drama.
Into the Storm is another found footage failure - a gimmicky natural disaster film that fails to provide exciting tornado action or impactful human drama.
Birdman provides a thought-provoking and inventive exploration of artistry, family, and the difference between power, popularity, and prestige.
Dumb and Dumber To isn't required viewing but with Carrey and Daniels back in the starring roles the sequel delivers a fair number of enjoyable (though moronic) laughs.
A solid entry in the series, and lays an intriguing foundation for Part 2, but Mockingjay - Part 1 is rarely as entertaining or rewarding as its predecessors.
Exodus: Gods and Kings is not an offensive Hollywood cash-grab, nor is it a particularly inventive revision of the Exodus story.
While The Babadook is a well-crafted, insightful, and overall excellent film, it's not going to be for everyone.
Viewers who give Aronofsky a chance will find that, despite differences of opinion and belief, there's plenty of universal value in this gripping tale of good overcoming evil.
Into the Woods struggles to fine tune prior iterations for the big screen and find its own identity but it's still an enchanting and entertaining musical experience.
Annie lands in an uninventive middle ground - it isn't necessary (or an improvement) but it isn't a total disaster either.
Interstellar is an imaginative movie, but a heavy-handed mix of personal sacrifice and theoretical physics doesn't leave much room for subtle storytelling.
Lucy will not speak to a wide audience but those that fall within its target reach should be rewarded with some thought-provoking science fiction.
Before I Go to Sleep does little to redefine the psychological thriller genre but still offers an intriguing central mystery that should keep viewers guessing.
For a heart-warming movie that praises risk taking and out of the box thinking, Million Dollar Arm plays its narrative surprisingly safe.
Boyhood is a noteworthy accomplishment - and an unparalleled movie experience.
Draft Day is an enjoyable and sentimental sports drama that, sadly, falls short of greatness - one that might also require die-hard football fans to suspend serious disbelief.
Outside of a few entertaining action moments, Brick Mansions is a clumsy mess that rarely lands a memorable punch.
Some will be underwhelmed by Neighbors' reliance on laughs over substance but most viewers will find plenty to enjoy in its outrageous comedy setups and likable characters.
Dom Hemingway delivers on half of its well-meaning intentions - prioritizing eccentric comedy beats over its unconventional tale of love and self-reflection.
A crowd-pleasing return for Godzilla with poignant human drama, blockbuster spectacle, and a third act brawl that sets a new bar for the King of the Monsters.
There's a tenderness to the story that should connect with modern moviegoing (blended) families but the film is held back by Sandler's usual low-brow humor and cheap gags.
For cinephiles that enjoy artistic debate more than concrete answers, Under the Skin provides an intriguing platform for discussion and reflection.
A heartfelt drama, where a pair of teenage protagonists set the stage for an ageless (and uplifting) message about human life - highlighting both its frailty and beauty.
A jumbled mix of on-the-nose comedy set pieces and contrived emotional threads that squander any potential within Sex Tape's entertaining premise.
Short on laugh-out-loud comedy beats - while also failing to find the 'heart' that made similar genre farces like Blazing Saddles timeless comedy classics.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Age of Extinction won't win over Transformers movie skeptics but Michael Bay succeeds in giving his fans what they are looking for - unmatched CGI spectacle.
Jersey Boys is an enjoyable but ultimately straightforward stage-to-screen transfer - over-polished and lacking in the raw energy that made its source material so enchanting.
It might not be the scariest movie of the year but, thanks to a compelling look at evil in our world, Deliver Us From Evil is still very frightening.
A bigger, and arguably better, sequel experience that features more dragons, larger scale action set pieces, as well as a poignant message on the challenges of growing up.

movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
A dense, baffling, thoroughly original epic that seems to divide viewers on the simple question of what it's supposed to be about.
A satire with much of the wit of her [Heckerling's] 1995 Clueless.
What Mendes delivers is a mixed blessing: a Bond film so self-serious it condescends to the frivolities it pretends to honor.
Like Kushner's Angels in America, Lincoln is less a literal history than a work that uses a historical moment to meditate on grand themes.
By now, the most interesting thing about Lynch's cult-classic debut may be the evidence it offers of how fully his sensibility was formed.
Health care is a difficult subject to make compelling onscreen -- much less in a nonpartisan manner -- which makes Escape Fire a documentary with major breakout potential.
movie_title: Escape Fire: The Fight to Rescue American Healthcare (2012)

movie_review_blurb: You'll feel like you need a helmet in the theater.
Always accessible, the doc lays out pros and cons of each medium.
The basic joke keeps on giving and the sweetness of the parent-child bonding scenes plays well.
The movie loses goodwill early on by killing an adorable dog, resulting in a lack of an identification point, since the canine has better intuition than the humans.
The presence of a film crew may have encouraged drama.
The film's notion that the ruse here was okay because it ultimately helped people seems like a specious rationalization.
Springs insists on maintaining just enough comedy to keep the project commercial, which essentially means reducing two protagonists with a long-shared history to caricatures.
Ultimately an ode to Rodriguez's artistic modesty and the power of his music-a rousing crowd-pleaser that asks you to save questions for another film.
Surely more topical (and essential) now than when it was conceived, The Queen of Versailles plays like a Christopher Guest parody of the financial crisis.
After a wobbly start, The Dark Knight Rises ascends in grand fashion, offering a respite from the digital murk and rote name-checking of the season's other comic-book movies.
Wallowing in the same adolescent nihilism as his Sin City, this adaptation of Frank Miller's graphic novel suffers from a similar lack of momentum.
Kick-Ass gains significant momentum in its second half, once it abandons the arch origin-story material and starts staking a claim as a straight-up action flick.
Depending on your POV, it's either the ne plus ultra of Hollywood calculation or a comedy simply intent on pushing its crassness to the point of surrealism.
This is On the Road as experienced by someone who exhibits no personality, a story of self-discovery in which there's no self to discover.
To an even greater degree than Copy, this movie about misinterpretation insists on keeping its audience guessing, maintaining an ambiguity about its intentions that lingers well after the final shot.
As far as entertainment value is concerned, the David Cronenberg "virus" thrives. Despite a few too many last-act rug-pulls, so does the movie.
The reduction in spontaneity lowers the risks. Unsurprisingly, the best jokes fall closest to the old, topical template.
Martini coasts on ambience and good song choices (some associated with the films of his executive producer, Martin Scorsese) and rallies with a refreshingly ambiguous ending.

Colon cancer isn't a great pretext for uplift or an occasion for Bucket List-style hang gliding, snappy dream-sequence banter with Whoopi Goldberg as God and a brief comic bit featuring Peter Dinklage as an escort.
Anyone seeking proof that a movie can transcend its subject should look to Silver Linings Playbook.
The Uninvited may strike even viewers who don't know the original as disarmingly familiar.
The catering-ad backdrops, pouty nonperformances and cheap-looking effects still dominate.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: [Perry] has rarely been less convincing than when locking and loading from his home arsenal or dangling from a decaying Detroit edifice.
Quote not available.
Quietly, empathetically, and without ever apologizing for the lead's impulsive idiocy, Frances Ha charts the character's dawning independence and acceptance of adulthood.

The film proceeds with a lazy, sketch-like feel that makes more sense after considering that these characters began on stage; the material was reconceived as a movie after a TV pilot failed to ignite.
A half-reverent, half-travestying adaptation that's campy but not a betrayal, offering a lively take on a familiar work while sacrificing such niceties as structure, character, and nuance.
As movies have taught us before (and no doubt will again), a little Mediterranean sunshine and a few plucks of soundtrack mandolin go a long way toward healing heartache.

Alternating scenes of the psycho-as-family-man with an increasingly grisly and desperate series of hits, it makes for a surprisingly monotonous sit for a movie that also features a killer named Mr. Freezy.
Once the shock of seeing a Sonic Drive-In in a Malick film wears off, the movie leaves little to ponder beyond the sketchily drawn romance drama at its core.
Niccol helps The Host survive as a sci-fi movie even as he's saddled with the Twilight author's source material.
Not just a step forward. It's a vision: a fever dream of sun-dappled debauchery that doubles as a thriller-satire on the allure of excess.
Petzold renders Communist oppression in a provocatively muted manner.
There's talent here, but the goal seems to be proving that everyone involved is too cool to make an actual movie.
Diary is less a movie about the necessity of faith than what it means to be cut down in the midst of youthful idealism and intransigence, before life offers wisdom.
movie_title: Diary of a Country Priest (Journal d'un curé de campagne) (1954)

movie_review_blurb: Taking a healthy swig from Lord of the Rings' cup, this high-concept "Jack and the Beanstalk" dresses up traditionalism in expensive nothingness.
The King's Speech is an entertainingly crafted movie that doesn't linger too long in the mind.
Makes for an intriguing if dispassionate fit.
Neither the Kentucky-fried turkey its unceremonious release suggests nor the kind of daring film maudit that seems destined to be reassessed decades hence.
The decade-spanning Zero Dark Thirty comes freighted with a historical weight it bears amazingly well.
After Gone Baby Gone, The Town and now this directorial-best, Affleck is establishing himself as a major craftsman.
One mourns the tragic circumstances that caused it to be made, but the result is a sleight of hand to rank alongside Orson Welles's F for Fake.
The film is way too earnest to inspire much anger. Some messages are better delivered with a flamethrower.
As retreads go, Django Unchained is as much a comedown from its predecessor as Lars von Trier's Manderlay was from Dogville.
Jack Reacher includes sufficient eccentricities to keep it enjoyably strange.
Jackman's Valjean can't quite sing on key. / And Crowe's Javert deserves Razzies.
One might be tempted to write off The Guilt Trip as overly familiar, but Barbra Streisand volunteering for a one-hour steak-eating challenge is almost certainly a screen first.
The movie teems with the excitement of unwrapping a present, even as it deals more seriously with the intractability of blood ties.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Bradley delivers some cleanly cut action and some grimy, modest mise-en-scene, though neither compensates for the goofiness of the plot, which dates from a less globalized planet.
Quote not available.
movie_title: La Danse -- Le Ballet de l'Opera de Paris (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is clear-eyed and fearless in its recounting of the horrors of civil war, if also somewhat unsettling in demonstrating the power of documentary to desensitize viewers to even the most appalling atrocities.
movie_title: Pray the Devil Back to Hell (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If Rudd steals the show, Segel deserves props for downplaying Sydney's regressiveness.

movie_review_blurb: All [Emmerich] cares about is not being boring. On that level, he succeeds.
Mara and Gallner make an attractive couple on the lam and Haley, as Freddy Krueger, hams it up to an almost alarming degree.
There's nothing extraordinary about No Country for Old Men -- except, of course, the spectacle of two great directors in total command of their craft.
The flatness of the Flash animation keeps visual bombast to a minimum, even during surreal interludes.
WALL-E sparks with genuine creativity.
Apart from the ecofriendly message, we have, as always, Miyazaki's magnificently inventive animation, which is almost enough to carry the day.
Marjane's outlook on events is always slightly skewed and caricatured, and the visuals keep Persepolis striking to the eye even during its less dramatically satisfying patches.
This is the kind of personal filmmaking that could only have come together through a chance set of inspirations. Maybe you could call it fate.
From start to finish, this is filmmaking at its most immortal.

Parkhill, far too eager to wow them in the end, has crafted a twist-is-everything scenario, evincing a sub-Mamet level of concern for plot holes or audience satisfaction.
Quote not available.
The Aristocrats is most enjoyable as a series of riffs.
Roos forecasts and explains every development with a title card, a device not unlike having someone yammering in your ear throughout the entire feature run time.

Director Stephen Marshall is more activist than film theorist, prone to editorializing ('I'm certainly not going to sacrifice profits,' one journalist character sneers) without the equivalent of Wexler's formal rigor.
Kirby Dick (Derrida) shapes the movie in such a way as to leave everyone flummoxed.
An honorable but dull attempt to translate a neglected literary source to the screen.
movie_title: The Bridge of San Luis Rey (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Based on characters created by Rodriguez's then-seven-year-old son, Racer Max, the film doesn't belong in wide release. It belongs on a refrigerator door, alongside '100%' spelling tests, old lunch menus, and notices from the PTA.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Those looking for a refresher course on the workings of the food chain should be in heaven. All others may yearn for a sushi break.
A lean, effective slice of agitprop enlivened with a New Wave voice-over and an unusual emotional directness.
First-time writer-director Richard Ledes's mystical tone and pervasive swipes from David Lynch tend to suffocate his satire, and stunt casting doesn't help.
The chemistry between diaper salesman Ashton Kutcher and photo hound Amanda Peet is so off that the pairing scans as an alienation effect.
Impotent.
Even the sitcom stylings might not matter if the movie were funny, but in spite of the potential for Guffman-esque comedy, The English Teacher boasts few surprises ...
Robots is a corporate product, after all -- but a sleek one.
The scariest thing in the movie is a cameo by Scott Baio.
The story seems awkwardly positioned between coming-of-age realism and whimsical fantasy.
As modest conspiracy-mongering, the movie is perfectly robust, earning its dramatic impact from its classical sense of intrigue and Philippe Torreton's testy performance in the title role.
Music is one universal language. Pandering is another.
The lowest form of cinematic life, a movie so utterly degenerate it makes you wish that indie filmmakers had to prove a basic standard of decency in order to buy a camera.
Takes a potential hot-button premise -- the callous indifference of the Indian medical bureaucracy toward the lower classes -- and dramatizes it in the most shameless way possible.
The film mostly shoots blanks; it's less than the sum of its in-jokes.
From the co-workers' macho hazing rituals to the pseudo-arty gotcha ending, New Guy never quite locates a sensibility to call its own.
It maintains a refreshingly unsentimental trajectory.
The notion that every generation is fundamentally the same gets hammered home so relentlessly that it becomes suffocating,
movie_title: Postmen in the Mountains (Nashan naren nagou) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A serviceable testament to the firemen who would bravely risk their lives to protect the safety of others, etc., etc.
Deadline delivers a routine but effective case against capital punishment.
'I'm scared to death that I'm gonna look like an idiot,' he tells his friends. (Too late.)
First Daughter is less amusing than Jenna and Barb at the RNC, and dumb enough to make last January's presidential scion, Mandy Moore, look electable.
A hand grenade lobbed at no place in particular.
Tame and cheesy even by the modest standards of the genre, Eternal needs all the intellectual trappings it can find.
Because the metaphysics driving it are so fuzzy, this is the rare horror film where even sludgy viscera elicit only yawns.
It takes a certain gall to pass off mere references as jokes.
The most that can be said for this strenuously bland reconstitution is that Steve Martin was clearly alive during filming. But just how alive, unfortunately, is at issue.
Jake [is] forced to swallow his pride and ask girly Brewster to train him. It's a marginally subversive moment in a movie that otherwise falls in line.
... a taut brainwashing thriller ...
There's no guiding power at work here; it's Evolution without a shred of intelligent design.
Forget 30-minute delivery -- this brand of indie quirkiness congealed in the late '90s.
Sitcom pizzicato underlines each comic development.
The Kid & I qualifies as the most indulgent kind of homemade project, laden with tediously inspirational dialogue and visuals that seem shot through half-fizzled Yuengling.
Pleasant even without reaching much of a destination.
It's a sour, petty act of mockery that values its own ineptitude over genuine cleverness, travestying Quentin Tarantino and others simply for dreaming up gimmicks that worked.
Never acquires the emotional weight it should.
By the time the sky really does start 'falling' -- courtesy of an alien invasion -- Chicken Little's frantic efforts to stay farm fresh have started to wear on the nerves.
This family-versus-business parable comes across as slight, familiar, and in dire need of seasoning.
Not quite a romance by numbers, Prime is nevertheless a movie we need like a hole in the head.
Title notwithstanding, Three . . . Extremes really offers only two. The first is one of nausea.

movie_review_blurb: Subversive yet heartwarming - it's a joy to watch.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's impossible not to be sucked into Akerman's final film.
A fully-fledged horror complete with all manner of squeamish moments.
Best described as a poetic and philosophical essay rather than a traditional doc.
A knotty, funny, ambiguous character study with an exceptional turn from Rebecca Hall.
Wise beyond her years, [Nika, played by Bronislawa Zamachowska] has a curt, verging on antagonistic relationship with her old man, but she's a ray of light in an otherwise grave endeavour.
[Salt and Fire] is littered with preposterous musings and every line intentionally overwritten to surreal effect.
Tribute is paid to Pablo Neruda's memory by mixing an exquisite and irreverent cocktail of his passions: poetry, politics and pulp.
The land is glorious and forbidding and the soundtrack's howling winds whip up and exacerbate the feeling of isolation, but onwards they plod.
That is Kieslowski's underlying point; that each death is a morally repugnant as the other -- and A Short Film About Killing tackles that subject with gloomy poetry and undeniable power.
Suwichakornpong confidently defies conventional forms and linearity. She collapses the past into the present as a way to probe the haunted recesses of both national and personal memory.
movie_title: By the Time It Gets Dark (Dao khanong) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a film swimming in symbolism, transgressive eroticism and perplexing details that will infuriate some audiences but for others will add to its irresistible allure.
There's ample complexity and nuance written into these issues and characters, but it only intermittently coalesces to truly satisfying ends.
It's just a shame that despite some funny moments, Pitch Perfect 3 isn't quite the same quality of material as before, meaning the Bellas close on something of a bum note.
The characters are not unfeeling automatons, but the almost Brechtian removal of sentimental cues makes the observations about our baser instincts all the more confrontational.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There are no set pieces here, which there could well have been. The director is not tempted to employ familiar techniques of shooting or representing this events usually confined to horror movies.
Poitras places her unreliability on centre stage, and in doing so, makes sure that we're acutely aware of how she - and indeed Julian Assange - want us to digest each frame of Risk.
This is a film portraying patriarchal misogyny, not condoning it. However, Verhoeven has no interest in delivering his biting critiques in easily digestible pieces.
The visuals echo the sensation of running your hand over a surface, giving Aquarius a completely apposite tactile quality that Dona Clara would cherish.
There's perhaps little of Free Fire that will linger too long in the memory after the credits roll, but there's still fun to be had.
Moonlight is a rich and profound character study grappling with questions of race, masculinity, sexuality, class, and love with unerring confidence and poetry.
It's as a scrupulous whole that Spotlight truly shines as one of the year's finest and most compelling dramas.
Its title may refer to an undeniably physical barrier but Tadhg O'Sullivan's The Great Wall... opts for a more transmutable definition of no more permeable boundaries.
La La Land is finely cut, A-grade nostalgia that proves nigh-on-impossible to resist.
While Into the Inferno is not Herzog's tightest work, it offers no fewer riches.
The most damning indictment of Suicide Squad is that it's unrelentingly bland.
"It's unlikely you're going to come across too many documentaries this year with a yarn to spin as tangled and twisted as Tickled."
Yet another contradiction at the heart of the fascinating and stimulating Kate Plays Christine: it speaks her name whilst wishing she'd been left to rest.
Even as she challenges accepted mythologies, she crafts her own both warning against nostalgia and passionately arguing for it; both being seduced and seducing at once.
The Cinema Travellers acts as both paean and elegy for this declining but inherently charming mode of exhibition.

[Morris'] film makes for a fittingly positive monument to [Dorfman's] often overlooked and under-appreciated work, but this intimate conversation and reflection also allows him to also do so much more.
movie_title: The B-Side: Elsa Dorfman's Portrait Photography (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Hansen-Løve's unobtrusive and novelistic approach doesn't see Nathalie embark on a spiral of loneliness or an arc of self-discovery, but a tide of breakthroughs and setbacks punctuated by grace and grief.
Stewart is exceptional in the lead role, her awkwardness a product a woman looking for meaning, whether in a haunted house or through the ping of a new SMS message.
An agonising procedural that records the slow death-rattle in a mordant and stifling chamber piece.
movie_title: The Death of Louis XIV (La mort de Louis XIV) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Gut-wrenchingly powerful, not least through its chilling and upsetting climax.
Grounds its outrageousness with an undercurrent of knowing sarcasm, much like its winning star.
A film that slowly constructs the dislocation and oppression that Olga feels.
Moana is a toe-tapping, heart-stealing adventure packed with laughs and featuring a kick-ass princess with nary a love interest on the horizon.
The Autopsy of Jane Doe is good genre fun - if little more.
Both a humane character study and issue-driven polemic.
A clunky and turgid affair, albeit one with a few bizarre moments thrown into the mix to keep audiences on their toes.
Johnson is pushing the audience to see these images as a dialogue between herself and these subjects, both in the frame of her representation of them and their impact on her.
Even when little of substance seems to be happening, the narrative feels propulsive.
The spectacularly unfunny supporting cast -- including Dave Foley, Jeffrey Tambor and David Koechner -- doesn't help either. But luckily Kutcher is there to try to clean up the mess.
Better Luck Tomorrow, a corrosive, insightful study of the pressure-packed lives of suburban high school students, brings a new variant to gangster movies: gangsters with perfect SAT scores.
Quote not available.
With performers as good as these and the freshness of Bill Condon's screenplay and Marshall's direction, there's really very little wrong with Chicago. What it lacks is something intangible -- heat.

A wonderfully weird bit of French animation that amounts to little but a celebration of its creator's bountiful imagination, yet manages to enthrall because writer-director Sylvain Chomet is such a solid visual storyteller.
A wan attempt to transpose the sports-movie formula onto the extreme-sports scene, Grind achieves extremes only of lameness.
When Farrell's on screen, Daredevil becomes more than just a finely tuned entertainment machine. In a movie that will rake people in no matter what, it's fun to see something unexpected.
The worst thing about Rugrats Go Wild is that the Rugrats have dragged the Thornberrys down into the diaper bag with them.
Fascinating and ferocious, Lizzie takes a legend hardened by history and blows it up from the inside, forcing the viewer to pick up the pieces and recontextualize this figure in a whole new light.
Mandy is a totally uncompromising vision from a singular filmmaker - a pulsing, twisted descent into heavy metal vengeance that must be seen to be believed.
Sadly, this film stumbles in its telling from its opening moments, and one problem quickly rises above the rest: Paul Rudd is heinously miscast in this role.
An impressive blockbuster that does exactly what it says.
The boys may well love Mandy Lane, but cinemagoers are best advised to stay well away from her and the shockingly abysmal film that bears her name.
movie_title: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This superb film shows, his conversations with Richard Nixon were far more illuminating than his recent banter with Lloyd Grossman.
Ultimately, there simply wasn't enough narrative development to justify a feature length film.
Well worth seeing for the barrage of genuine laugh-out-loud moments in its first half, The Other Guys is an example of a movie that peters out by conforming to storytelling convention.
It's great fun.
Get Smart certainly has its moments, but suffers badly from an inability to balance the surreal humor and life-threatening terrorist threat.

Tyler Perry movies certainly have their place in society, as they undoubtedly have a strong moral core and are made with noble intentions. On the evidence of For Colored Girls though, he should leave the serious drama alone.
Just how was this staggeringly poor script given the green light?
The cracking performances from Alba and Cook do wonders at papering over these creative fissures.
Stone has a glittering career as a leading lady ahead of her.
An execrable movie that's incredibly uninspired.
Shooter is nothing special, but a combination of appealing performances, intriguing plot twists and exciting action sequences mean that we're never less than entertained.
While a disappointment, The Ward is by no means a complete dud.
It's a shame that the painstaking work of the CGI animators was ultimately doomed to failure by the script.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The real thrill of the film lies in watching these two men, sat on various sides of the moral fence, gradually converge and respect each other.
Quite possibly the best film of the year, it is to be seen at all costs.
An action blockbuster with rollercoaster thrills and laughs that has a fundamentally intelligent core.
Fingers crossed that this turns into a franchise, as Mick Haller is such a charismatic and intriguing character with many layers still to be peeled.
The real battle in this duff alien invasion movie is whether the direction is worse than the writing.
Not every movie needs to be a thought-provoking work of art...

Expecting logic from the director of the wonderful Con Air is not the wisest move, yet Simon West frequently depicts events in such a baffling manner that one wonders whether someone snuck into the editing suite with a pair of scissors.
A supremely rewarding film, Black Swan harnesses its complex subject matter through Aronofsky's genius and uniformly excellent portrayals of the damaged characters.
Described by Boyle as an "action movie with a guy who can't move", 127 Hours is a dynamic gem that makes for thrilling, if often uneasy, viewing.

For all of the hundreds of animators who spent over a year painstakingly assembling each pixel in the computer-generated world, not one person was employed who could write a competent screenplay that harnessed their efforts.

The powerful performances by the leads, unobtrusive direction that is exemplified in a beguiling courtroom clash, and Larsson's deftly interwoven fabric of treachery and compassion all ensure that we are left yearning for more.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Eat lots of popcorn to distract you, pray for it to end, and love Richard Jenkins. Amen.
The amount of preposterous coincidences that lead to the precarious predicament of the three muppets and their continued suffering also robs Frozen of any remote credibility.
Affleck's direction adds visceral qualities that complement the cerebral merits of the movie.
Kevin Smith's latest offering provides a constant stream of laughs throughout its duration, but crucially fails to nail the emotional realism it tries so hard to achieve.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Soon we realize that Sicko hinges not on what Michael Moore is uncovering, but on what he's hiding. This is a real shame as he's a talented documentary maker.

Superb performances from James McAvoy and Robin Wright Penn alongside an increasingly focused narrative ensure that The Conspirator ultimately proves to be a rewarding experience with a powerful message.
The terrific dual performances in The Devil's Double ensure that this sensationalized account of Saddam Hussein's merciless son and his beleaguered lookalike is a worthwhile experience.
Sadly, while Juno may be able to carry a big bun in her oven, this film can't quite bear the heavy burden of expectation so well.
This magnificently realized musical from Stephen Sondheim contains the right blend of emotional pathos, stunning visuals and accessible songs.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Fifty Dead Men Walking is a largely uninvolving crime thriller that fails to do justice to the intriguing story of an informant within the IRA.

Savour one of cinema's rawest talents finally powerslamming his way to glory and be grateful that Aronofsky dragged himself off the ropes on countless occasions to convince the money men to finance the movie with such a seemingly unbankable lead actor.

The actors try their best to transcend the flimsy script and unappealing direction, but ultimately the movie offers a mostly hollow experience that delivers a night that you will struggle to remember.
Winter's Bone is a rewarding watch that does repay a fairly slow-moving narrative with heightened tension and twists at the end.
This latest installment in the franchise is a near-perfect blockbuster that provides a myriad of visual and cerebral treats to devour.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Brighton Rock's pros and cons pretty much cancel each other out when assessed as a standalone movie, but it comes nowhere close to breaking free from the shackles of its 1947 antecedent.
A tense journey into the darkness of Middle America, Red State holds the power to both shock and amuse with its increasingly audacious story and strong performances.
Director Oliver Parker displays a shocking inadequacy at generating even a mild titter from a few moments that had the potential to be funny.
To be consistent with his previous efforts, Anderson deploys a relentless stream of fight sequences that revert to nauseating and outmoded slow-mo during moments of supposedly heightened tension.
As funny, spooky and marvellous as ever.
A powerful reminder of the magic of cinema and Martin Scorsese's astounding versatility...

A mesmerizing movie that veers towards an unbearably tense climax, The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo benefits from invigorating direction and superb acting that allows the old-fashioned mystery to unravel in a hugely satisfying and captivating way.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: After the infectious fun of JJ Abrams' M:I 3, which sparkled with the wit and charm of his espionage series Alias, the fourth installment is a thudding disappointment.
A waste of talent, it proves that the most important people involved in cinema are those responsible for the scripts. Whether there are flies buzzing around it or not, some turds cannot be polished.
Have low expectations for this movie and you might just be surprised.
Hunger will leave you feeling emotionally battered and bruised -- yet emerging from the cinema a stronger person for having witnessed such a beautiful and brutal film.
As the film drags on, there are several nauseatingly dogmatic moments that make you feel like you're trapped in some kind of uber-liberal rally.
It never feels contrived or overwritten, managing to deftly pack emotional punches through the strength of its performances and direction.
Seriously, you'll find yourself more emotionally and viscerally involved by sticking some Lego men in a water filled blender and watching them go round and round.
While the meagre rationing of shocks is undoubtedly frustrating for the bulk of the movie, this allows the final act plenty of room to crank the fear factor up to 11.
There is much to recommend in this reunion of the creative forces behind the dazzling first Saw movie.
Meet The Spartans? For those unlucky enough to be lured into the cinema, there's every chance you'll be wanting to meet your maker instead.

Sadly not a movie about the big-chinned ski jumper Eddie Edwards, this underwhelming feature instead revolves around the 'Ted and Ralph' style bromance between a master and servant during the Roman occupation of England.
