A heist-gone-wrong thriller that grips from the start and never lets go.
The movie is held together...by the fluidity of his style and his characteristic blend of lightness and gravity.
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A film which, while likely to serve as a campaigning document for civic associations and human rights groups, also provides a striking portrait of a remarkable individual.
We Blew It is far from being a routine run-through of a decade whose legacy continues to divide.

Mihaileanu's direction is uneven and it's tempting to speculate on what a filmmaker less intensely preoccupied with Jewish themes - such as Gravity director Alfonso Cuaron, who was initially slated to helm - might have made of it.

The performances by Schmidt and Bel are adequate, but Brasseur, who played opposite the likes of Jean Gabin back in the 1950s, is unable to get much change out of the stereotyped role of the old grump.
The chemistry [Anthony Hopkins and Colin Farrell] achieve is a powerful argument for giving Solace its chance on the multiplex circuit.
There's vaulting and flipping galore as well as the customary ration of fistfights, shoot-outs, car chases and general mayhem that should satisfy hardcore action fans.
What's troubling is its lack of perspective on anything beyond the narrow, navel-gazing concerns of its characters.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There's a sadness to this movie, but one that reflects the harshness of life itself - the sense of a lesson learnt the hard way.
Moviegoers who liked Taken and want more of the same will get precisely that.
A political parable with satirical bite.
Biopic of French proto-punk starts well but loses focus.

Luchini's trademark mannerisms, which in some films can be irritating, are here perfectly judged and appropriate. Zem confirms his growing stature as a boxoffice attraction, [and] Bourgoin does well to keep her character from veering into caricature.
movie_title: La Fille de Monaco (The Girl from Monaco) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Adaptation of gothic classic pleases the eye but ultimately disappoints.
Schamus' directorial debut is remarkable, capturing the male moodiness of Roth's work. The brilliant young leads only elevate the already rich material.
Schoenaerts delivers a volcanic performance in this deliberately paced, moody character study.
One of Pixar's most delightful offerings to date.
Pulpy, old-fashioned Western action and terrific performances make Hell or High Water one of the most satisfying releases of the summer.
Spaceman is a tonally confused, moderately entertaining glimpse into the life of one of baseball's most bizarre characters.
Krasinski demonstrates a real knack for getting his actors to gel and flow and do their jobs well.

Much like the great Grave of the Fireflies and Pixar's Up before it, Kubo and the Two Strings treats its audience with utmost respect, taking them on an exhilarating adventure while shining a light into the darkest corners of the human experience.
Southside With You is a sweet date movie that serves as an unexpected respite from the current firestorm of political absurdity.
The Light Between Oceans is a visually and thematically cohesive package, though its characters feel emotionally an arm's length away.

Taken bite by bite and with a measure of patience, Moorhouse's directorial return is as delightfully chaotic as Tilly's homecoming, a colorful, one-of-a-kind affair that's not afraid to shake things up a bit.
Its messaging is half-baked and blunt, but Nerve still manages to be a solid YA thriller that boasts more than a few heart-stopping set pieces.
The grief of displacement and financial inadequacy is real and devastating and informs much of Little Men, but so too does the equally authentic exhilaration of young friendship in the big city.
The Ice Age series hits even lower lows in this insolently implausible, laughless trek toward the apocalypse.
The Ones Below is a polished creepy-neighbor thriller that ramps up its dark intensity a little too much, resulting in a somewhat tiresome, overwhelming experience.
The Duel is a forgettable, muddled affair that wastes its two charismatic leads on endless scenes of tonal wonkiness.
Chilling and inexplicably fascinating, Tickled is a looping left hook of a documentary; it'll knock you out, and you won't know what hit you.
Swiss Army Man is a well-acted, disgusting, poignant filmic oddity that will be too strange for the squeamish and an absolute treasure for intrepid, open-minded moviegoers.
Made for fans, by fans, De Palma is a straightforward, riveting doc about one of the brightest movie minds we've ever known.
Clarke and Claflin shine in this mostly enjoyable tearjerker, though the filmmakers leave many of the story's most interesting themes and ideas largely unexplored.

It features a standout performance from a surging actress with a big future, and actually does some interesting things in its first hour. However, despite its strengths, the film falls flat as a pancake in its incomprehensible, bumbling third act.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Weiner is the most exhilarating political doc you'll see all year. This is fast-paced, hilarious, stranger-than-fiction entertainment.
Greta Gerwig learns to let the chips fall where they may in Rebecca Miller's witty, easygoing Maggie's Plan.
Sunset Song is an overly studied tale of female perseverance set in rural Scotland that lacks the dimension of Davies' previous work.
Volcanic, sumptuous and terrifically well-acted, A Bigger Splash is proof that Guadagnino is one of the most vital filmmakers working today.
Underneath a strange, body-horror plot lies a blistering Hong Kong action movie with the type of bone-crunching fight scenes that genre fans crave.
Diabolically, Garry Marshall smashes yet another national holiday to pieces with this banal, surprisingly offensive ensemble comedy.
Sing Street is a crowd-pleasing, glittery '80s nostalgia trip, and John Carney's most red-blooded effort yet.
A family of survivalist philosophers rail against the real world in Matt Ross' spellbinding, thought-provoking road drama.

Most are already keenly aware of how disgusting and deplorable hazing is, but Neel's film serves as a wake-up call for those who still perpetuate the tradition or don't view it as a deadly serious issue.
Pete's Dragon is a fun, unabashedly kid-friendly film that makes old-fashioned, simple storytelling cool again.
The boldness of Arnold's sweeping visual style and her uncanny command of mood and tone make American Honey a must-watch.
Jeauffre's blending of terrestrial and extraterrestrial imagery is hypnotizing and spectacular, but this story of survival feels too bloodless to appeal to the average viewer.
[Ryan] Coogler is one of the most exciting young filmmakers we've seen in a long time, and as long as he continues to tell his truth, he's going to go on to have a magnificent career.
Without question, Sean is the film's center of gravity.
movie_title: BPM (Beats Per Minute) (120 battements par minute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Mountain Between Us is an easily digestible romance that might have been more interesting if it were a bit harder to swallow.
Ryan Gosling's lead performance is actually better than Harrison Ford's was in the 1982 film, which isn't a knock on Ford but rather a testament to his successor's gifts.

Absolutely brimming with artistry and ambition, but is so punishing and painful to watch that it feels impossible to recommend to a friend for fear that they'll ultimately blame their inevitable, crippling, post-movie PTSD on you.
Cursory, dull, and as forgettable as any movie you'll see this year, The Dark Tower's best virtue is its brisk 90-minute runtime.
Off-kilter, idiosyncratic, and startlingly moving, Brigsby Bear speaks to a generation of young people who find friendship with others who share their unconventional obsessions.

Dunkirk is Nolan's most directly cinematic of his works, knocking plot and melodrama down the totem pole in favor of furiously transportive images and sounds that elicit emotion in a more primal, instinctual way.

It's pure exhilaration to watch this new, pitch-perfect version of the iconic hero swing high above the New York City streets, and if the movie's forthcoming sequels are as fun as this, Marvel Studios can keep 'em coming.

The Book of Henry is a hair away from being in league with the most ludicrous Lifetime original movies, but its cast, slick production and Trevorrow's willingness to take risks make it an oddball chunk of entertainment.
Cars 3 isn't remarkable or groundbreaking or even all that memorable, but it's a rock-solid movie that leaves a far better taste in the mouth than its critically panned predecessors.
Like its predecessors, Dead Men is a wishy-washy movie that isn't violent or edgy enough for adults but feels just a bit too disgusting and unsettling for kids.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The creature's return is, in fact, triumphant, as is Scott's return to the roots of his beloved sci-fi franchise.

Annabelle: Creation isn't groundbreaking or cutting-edge in the slightest, but it uses old-school techniques and top-notch sound design incredibly well, delivering a no-frills, all-chills horror experience...
The Zookeeper's Wife isn't nearly as unique or bizarre or harrowing as the events that inspired it, though it is deeply felt and, at times, unexpectedly charming.
[Kelly Reichardt is] one of the most important American filmmakers working today, and this may be her best work yet.
Despite some minor issues, Livolsi's debut is an absolute crowd-pleaser that will please adults and speak straight to the hearts of repressed, rowdy teens everywhere.
Though it's a bit of a wobbly mess at times, Hacksaw Ridge ultimately winds up being a deeply moving character study about an unlikely American hero.
If her accomplishments don't impress you for some reason, the sheer cuteness of her relationship with her trusty eagle will no doubt win you over.
The performances are stilted for the most part, with most scenes feeling melodramatic when meant to be tragic, flat as a pancake when meant to be funny.
Gervais' focus rests squarely on David's emotional implosion which, while acted and laid out quite well, is so punishing that one wonders whether it was worth checking back in on the poor guy at all.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A United Kingdom is well-intentioned, with impassioned performances from Oyelowo and Pike, but it's executed as drily and inoffensively as so many middling Brit period dramas.
The journey is corny and morally obvious, and yet rings true on certain levels thanks to Deutch's interpretation of the role.
Kong: Skull Island has a lot going for it, but what it gets really right is how it captures the unadulterated, intoxicating joy of watching the mighty Kong smash things to itty bitty pieces.
Raw is a film whose beauty is only revealed to those with a wide-open mind and an iron stomach.

I'm sure Malick and his editors had a focused intent when sequencing the imagery, but nothing so specific registers on the big screen. What it amounts to is an empty exercise in free association that becomes unbearably dull as the film wears on.
Frantz elevates a relatively conventional surface story with an understated but powerful sense of psychological terror.
The April-air wholesomeness and humanism of this natural bring back vividly the reminder that, essentially, the screen best offers unselfconscious, forthright entertainment.
If Gordon-Levitt (who's delivered stellar performances in Mysterious Skin and The Lookout) had been moved up from his supporting role to the lead, the film would improve considerably.
I haven't felt this embarrassed for a star since Robert DeNiro donned a tutu and did the can-can in Stardust.
As someone who has an aversion to most contemporary romantic movies, Wong is a filmmaker whose lush romanticism makes me swoon.
The new film The Grand should have been called Werner Herzog Steals the Show because that's precisely what he does in this mockumentary about a poker tournament.
To sum up The Ruins, I'll quote one of the characters: "This is so not okay."

Sanders provides a rare glimpse into the world of the doctors and nurses tasked with saving lives in difficult circumstances. You cannot leave Fighting for Life without a deep sense of respect for the medical personnel and the patients.
Zombie Strippers is hands - and arms, legs, feet and any other dismembered body part you have laying around - down the best comedy so far this year.
So while I might complain about some of Lee's filmmaking choices, I feel nothing but wonder and delight at seeing these dancers excel at something they love so passionately.
In the end, Surfwise is a fascinating portrait of a family that manages to be both radical and conventional, divided but still tightly bound by blood.
If you are planning to shoot a visual poem, there is no one better to have on hand than cinematographer Christopher Doyle. Doyle knows how to find seduction and romance anywhere.
It's noteworthy for the performances of Melvil Poupard as Romaine and Jeanne Moreau as the grandmother-two people facing their own mortality, and trying to exit this world with grace and dignity.
It also boasts another rich performance by Charlotte Rampling who continues to grow more interesting as an actress.

The choice of a Japanese director and a number of key Japanese crew seems to have helped make this American remake a notch better than the other atrocious remakes such as One Missed Call, Pulse and The Eye.
The film doesn't cover any new terrain for Ripstein -- which some may complain about - but its terrain that he knows well.
Rather than being the perfect first date movie, it serves up the perfect break up film. You might just laugh till you cry... or cry until you laugh if you're the one being dumped.
Knowing that something as outrageous as this could be true does give the film some added spice.
Embracing this film will depend on whether its charms triumph over its contrivances. I left impressed by the performances but disappointed by the film as a whole.
Brazil serves up one of the most breathtakingly imaginative worlds ever to be put on screen.
I spent most of the film's 148 minutes just wanting to slap these women because I grew weary of their whining.
The film works so well because it comes from something personal and you can't fake intimate details that come from life. You'll come out of this one cheering.
...lovesick prehistoric man traverses the globe to rescue the woman he loves.
The Strangers gets your hopes up with some smart filmmaking but then pretty much dashes them by the final predictable fade out.

This may not be what the Academy has in mind when it's considering the Oscar worthy performances but Downey finds the reality of being a superhero and makes us buy into that. Final verdict: Iron Man is cool and Downey is hot.
Rarely does a film employ the frame so fully and serve up images of such breathtaking scale as in The Fall.
The Children of Huang Shi means well and actually has a solid story at its core. But what Spottiswoode and company do to that good story is unforgivable.
Joachim Trier's brash cinematic sampling draws on diverse sources yet it spins something defiantly fresh and original.
Light on its feet, deeply human, and fresh in style, this French-Israeli co-production serves up an engaging tale about a group of women struggling with daily life in contemporary Tel Aviv.
The film had no opening credits, except for the title 88 Minutes. Maybe that's because no one wanted to take credit for this mess.
The open got my interest up because the animation style recalled the Emmy-winning Cartoon Network show Samurai Jack. Unfortunately, when the dream ends, so does the innovative visual style...
Ford and Spielberg are all a little older and a little slower. But the film works because they have all retained a sense of fun... This isn't great art, just great fun.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: But what makes the film such wicked fun is the way Tarantino delivers the familiar with a twist. He continually prepares us for one thing and then delivers another.
[Bose's T.K.] is both an observer and a reluctant participant in the tragedy, and in Bose's performance we see the intellectual awakening and politicization of a young man.
Son of Rambow conveys the passion and imagination of these kids... But what the film also does is to place their fantasies in a very real context.
[Dujardin] has a goofy and endearing smile, and somehow manages to combine Sean Connery's suave appeal with the pomposity and incompetence of Peter Sellers' Inspector Clouseau.
movie_title: OSS 117: Le Caire Nid d'Espions (OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: ...bland family fare with high end production values. It feels about as real as a Disneyland ride, and what a fantasy film needs to do is convince you of is that even the most fanciful thing in its imagined universe is absolutely real.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If you love good story telling, an intricate plot, cute young Japanese stars, and a punky shinigami, you won't find a film better than Death Note... unless it's Death Note 2.

The racial stereotypes that emerge in this film are as over the top and potentially offensive as Eli Wallach's Tuco in The Good, the Bad and the Ugly. But what redeems the film to some degree is its general good naturedness...
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Making a film about the Holocaust but using a very specific and personal story is what makes The Counterfeiters stand out. It's the specifics of Sorowitsch's story that rivet us.
One terrifying scene involves the sewing up of Bauby's paralyzed eye. He can still out of it but can't blink to lubricate it. The scene's as scary as anything in a horror film.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Bollywood films, more than films from anywhere else in the world, harken back to the heyday of the Hollywood studio star system with all the glamour and gloss that goes with that.

I find it fascinating to get this window into North Korea... Seeing these North Korean films you realize that we have more than we might have imagined in common despite the vast political and sometimes cultural differences.
The characters are so rich and so human that they transcend the simple animation.The vocal performances also help give the film universal appeal.
The film offers a heartbreaking drama told in reverse chronology and spanning twenty years in both the life of the main character and the political history of Korea.

The film reveals the penchant of South Korea filmmakers to mix every genre imaginable into one film. This one blends goofy comedy, war drama, tragedy, action and social commentary for a highly entertaining ride.
Now if they could just pipe in the smell of sweat, pot and beer, it would be exactly like going to a concert.
Imagine Hostel with a CSI twist and done for the Oxygen network crowd, and you'll have an idea of what Untraceable is like.
After seeing Cloverfield, I was so frustrated and disappointed that I felt like I needed a palate cleanser. I wanted to immediately go home and watch South Korea's The Host.
The film aims low but it keeps hitting its mark with hilarious accuracy. The bottom line for a comedy is, does it make you laugh? This one does.
Imagine Little Miss Sunshine and Alien mixed together and you'll have an inkling of what South Korea's The Host has in store for you.
The Orphanage is a thinking person's ghost story. It builds slowly and pays off stunningly.
The Bucket List dies long before the characters do.

Beineix choreographs the actors and the camera into a stunning and stylish cinematic dance... This is not a musical in the strict sense of the word but it certainly feels like one in the way it moves.
This bond of trust between the filmmakers and their subjects exemplifies the kind of personal involvement that many documentary makers are striving for these days.
Now the studio has smartly served up an R-rated sequel so the blood could flow, and it does. Unfortunately, it doesn't flow with much imagination.

Russell scores big by casting young Alex Etel as Angus. Etel made us believe in saints in the film Millions. Now he makes us believes that a computer generated water horse is a living and breathing creature.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Seeing Tolson expose his young students to the poets of the Harlem Renaissance and instilling in them a sense of pride and rebellion is inspiring... Tolson is a fascinating character who could command an entire movie himself.
There Will Be Blood is as close to perfection as you will find in a movie. It's dark and bleak in its material yet uplifting in the beauty of its craftsmanship.
This film is like a bull in a China shop -- it just keeps charging forward, destroying everything in its path.
Nanking is a sometimes clumsy and sometimes artistically flawed documentary but in the end it presents a powerful account of what happened in Nanking at the end of 1937 and beginning of 1938.
The film moves with such joy, humor and fluidity that you can't help getting swept up in the frenzied action.
Teixeira brings his camera into her home and quietly records the details of her daily life. The result is a carefully observed film about one woman's growing dissatisfaction.
I might almost sit through the crappy storytelling one more time just to see the car chases. These are the kind car chases that Stuntman Mike from Death Proof might be able to appreciate
The Signal reveals killer horrors skills on the part of Bruckner, and to a lesser extent of Gentry and Bush. So if you don't mind a film that starts strong and finishes weak, check it out.
What becomes interesting is how Ace and Wallace, who have managed to stay outside the violence for the most part, start to get pulled in once they uncover information about their fathers.
The film succeeds because of the nuanced performances of its superb cast, and because of Kolirin's witty visual compositions.
The Other Boleyn Girl turns British history into a chick flick soaper with high production values and A-list actors.
Like its main character, Charlie Bartlett tries so hard to win us over that it practically bursts a celluloid vein in the process...Yet you can't deny that they both have impressive energy.
His film unfolds with a graceful realism, as if he just happened to catch life unfolding for these two desperate women. His film never hits a false note...

Moreau and Palud decide to trade in the creepy, atmospheric style of the Pang Brothers for a more amped up Hollywood approach...it fails to distinguish itself either as a remake or on its own terms as a horror film.
Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show is a modest documentary that provides a good showcase for these four comedians.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: McDonagh shines more as a writer than director but he displays a fresh, darkly comic take on life that's quite welcome.

Gibney's film proves a cogent document that people need to see because there seems to be a willingness to accept the current policies without really thinking about what that means... Gibney's film asks us to think and to question.
There's a refreshing adult quality in the film that kicks the film a notch above the rest of the romantic and comic fare currently available.
Jumper is so bad that it might be useful in film classes to show students what not to do.
Weber's documentary serves up an exquisite fusion of filmmaking style and subject matter to serve up a film that captures the essence of cool.
Waters does ground his film in the real world, and more importantly he creates a real sense of the family dynamics before Jared opens the door to the world of goblins and woodland creatures.
In just the opening minutes, Romero reveals more filmmaking smarts than most horror films display in two hours.
You'll find deliciously low budget sets Ed Wood would die for; a know-it-all robot; babes in bathing suit space uniforms; and a refreshing Mexican take on American sci-fi conventions.
movie_title: La Nave de los Monstruos (The Ship of Monsters) (1960)

movie_review_blurb: Roman de Gare is a sleek, attractive package made even more appealing by a trio of exquisite performers.
The Year My Parents Went on Vacation is an appealing dramedy that delicately couches its political and social commentary in a coming of age tale.
movie_title: The Year My Parents Went on Vacation (O Ano em Que Meus Pais Saíram de Férias) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Irina Palm is a showcase for Faithfull but it never truly allows her to shine.
Inkheart has an engaging premise in its notion of a Silvertongue and a refreshing love of books.
I have to say that I did enjoy seeing Tony Blair/David Frost/Michael Sheen strutting around in an action film. The incongruity was most enjoyable.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's a kung fu action comedy played out to a Bollywood beat.

Folman functions much like the therapist who carefully leads a patient through a minefield of difficult memories and emotions, bringing together pieces bit by bit until we're ready to confront and accept the truth.
Let the Right One In is so fresh and original that it makes what's currently available in horror seem stale and formulaic.

Like Jamal, Slumdog Millionaire succeeds against all odds and in ways that you think are impossible. In our cynical, contemporary times, it delivers a romantic fable that's as rich, complex, and beautiful as the city it comes from.
In The Express the football field is a place where people of very diverse backgrounds are forced to work together for a common goal and what happens on the field proves to have broader implications.
As with Cloverfield, I started rooting for the monster to eat the people at a faster rate.
His sophomore feature, Boy A explores bleak territory but its insistence on not tying everything up in neat little bows is to be commended.
I would pay to see this film again if only for Rickman... Rickman's performance, like so much of his work, is sheer perfection and a delight to watch.
Mamma Mia! has an exclamation in its title for a reason: it just wants to shout out its sense of fun. The film is buoyantly unpretentious and proclaims at the top of its voice, "Take me as I am."
It's a film that looks like a big dumb comedy but it proves to have some satiric smarts underneath. Stiller succeeds in deftly satirizing an industry he knows well and seems unafraid of skewering.
Produced by Judd Apatow and written by Seth Rogen and Evan Goldberg, Pineapple Express serves up a combination of The Big Lebowski, True Romance, and Hot Fuzz.
I know The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor is nothing more than a popcorn movie... But even silly pop movies have standards and this one falls short of those.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Petit himself is a bundle of energy, passion, and enthusiasm as he describes his dreams and the nuts and bolts details of achieving it. Marsh lets the story play out like a heist film.
Now only a pot comedy would conceive of turning George W. into a goofy, dare I say even likable pothead who's afraid of his dad and Dick Cheney.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Stiller should get an Oscar for his performance as Fineman and that's no joke. This is a role of a lifetime and Stiller relishes the opportunity.
Wendy and Lucy is a delicate and compassionate portrait of someone living precariously on the edge, and it asks us to respond to their predicament with kindness rather than indifference.
It's far better than any of the horror remake crap coming out and it earns its laughs honestly by actually intending to be funny.
All the slickness works against the remake because it helps to distance the audience from the unpleasantness on the screen.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: District 9 delivers on all fronts %u2013 it's an imaginative sci-fi tale, a gritty actioner, a dazzling effects film, a compelling dramatic story, a biting satire, and a flat out exciting piece of pop entertainment.
Hayao Miyazaki proves that he is not only a master animator but also a master storyteller. Ponyo is easily one of the best films -- animated or live action -- of the year.

In one sense, The Hurt Locker is an old school war film %u2013 muscular, focused almost exclusively on men in combat, and not interested in politics or making a statement. But the film's also very contemporary.
The best thing that can come from this film is that it will be so poorly received both by critics and audiences that it will put a damper on Hollywood's current interest in remaking anime.
I have to give kudos to McDonald and Burgess for refreshing the zombie genre in ways I never thought possible.

You could say his new film The Hangover is the Reservoir Dogs of party movies. Reservoir Dogs was a heist film that never shows you the heist, and The Hangover is about a wild night in Vegas that only shows the aftermath.

Director Duncan Jones also taps into the visual style of Silent Running, which was directed by special effects wizard Douglas Trumbull. Taking his cue from Trumbull, Jones creates a vivid but far from perfect futuristic world.
Wright is a machine who thinks he's human and in that conundrum is the interesting story that the film essentially misses.
Egoyan is always in complete control of the material, letting us know details only when he chooses to reveal them and only when it serves the right purpose in the timeline of his story.
The filmmakers let our imaginations take flight with Carl's house and we willing tag along for the adventure.
I don't think Raimi's intent in his latest film is to scare the hell out of you but rather to give you a fun ride and Drag Me to Hell delivers exactly that.
I must add that the reason I think this new Star Trek works has less to do with Abrams being the director and more to do with a genuinely smart script by Roberto Orci and Alex Kurtzman.
This Friday the 13th commits the worst sin a horror movie can be guilty of - it was boring.
Amarcord is Fellini's scrapbook of memories culled from his own life and it is completely engaging and delightful.
Del Toro's performance is fine and there are many strong moments (including some wonderful black and white footage of Che in New York) but the parts are better than the whole.
The Class offers a compelling and naturalistic look at contemporary teaching and the challenges of a diverse classroom. The film eschews big Hollywood moments and instead goes for quiet telling ones.
Cherry Blossoms is an exquisitely and delicately crafted film about love, loss, and a kind of spiritual healing.

If you only buy one DVD this year make it Spaced. Seriously, it's funny. Very funny. This show will not only make you laugh, it will get better with each viewing as you pick up on more and more of the pop culture references.
Leone also endows the film with a clever visual style. His sense of scale is especially inspired.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly (1966)

movie_review_blurb: Ledger's manically endearing performance as the unhinged psycho giving both cops and crooks nightmares is so riveting that it makes you sad for all the roles he'll never have a chance to tackle.
Del Toro and Perlman essentially make you forget that Hellboy's this bizarre creature because Perlman invests him with such humanity. And maybe what makes him most human are his flaws.
Up the Yangtze is a beautifully crafted documentary. Chang displays artistry in the way he assembles his material. He captures China at a crossroads where he finds both guarded hope and epic sadness.
As with the anime series, the Bleach movie mixes furious action, with bittersweet drama and goofball comedy.
Tone and pace are absolutely crucial to comedy. If the tone is wrong or the pace is off - by even a hair - the comedy will shrivel up and die. And that's precisely what happens in The Promotion.
But in the end I think Bell is not so much pro-steroids but rather eager to open up a debate about the drug. He doesn't pretend to have answers but he's full of questions.
When Did You Last See Your Father? stands out mostly because of Jim Broadbent, and on the strength of his performance I would recommend the film.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Although the film seems very proud of its clever gender bending "twist," there's really nothing fresh about Made of Honor. It's a one-gag movie that wears out its gag well before the halfway mark.
This film may be based on real events but it plays out like a sharp and often absurd political satire.
The Rape of Europa boasts a strong narration by Joan Allen as it explores a less familiar aspect of World War II and the legacy left by the Nazis.
The Visitor presents a rich, complex world where people connect in unexpected ways. It is a fitting follow up to the themes McCarthy covered in The Station Agent.
The Life Before Her Eyes has the core of an inventive narrative and a twist that probably worked better as a literary device.
You'd think that with all the focus groups and test marketing Hollywood does that somewhere along the line someone would have said, "hey, don't you think this one strains credibility a bit too much?"
Although familiarity with Italian politics helps in appreciating this film, anyone can enjoy this energetic tale of a house divided.
movie_title: Mio Fratello è Figlio Unico (My Brother Is an Only Child) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Cinema Paradiso is for anyone who loves the movies. And Tornatore's final montage of glorious movie images reaffirms the power and magic of cinema.

So Redbelt poses as an action film but delivers what I would call an anti-action action picture. And by not delivering on expectations, Mamet satisfied me with something else, something much more clever.

Then She Found Me is a commendable but not very exciting feature-directing debut by actress Helen Hunt. Although she wields most of the creative power on the film she doesn't turn this into a vanity project.
In a film that feels so unstructured, these scenes reveal how much craft and structure actually go into Hou's films, how he endows his film with such meticulous layering of themes and ideas.

movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Master thespian Peter O'Toole proves he's still at the top of his game in [this] poignant, complicated tale about mortality and passion.
Human nature trumps all in [this] thoughtful, engrossing tale of intrigue and instinct in 1980s East Germany.
Heather Graham's nonstop perky chattering is more annoying than cute in [this] uneven, unrealistic romantic comedy about a rather bizarre love triangle.
Vivid and emotional--but also disjointed and melodramatic--Olivier Dahan's Edith Piaf biopic ... is all about Marion Cotillard's passionate performance.
Wistful and uneven, Jonathan Kasdan's [drama] is like Garden State by way of a John Hughes movie -- but less engaging than either.
Paul Verhoeven's well-acted but overblown (and overly long) WWII thriller ... is like The Diary of Anne Frank by way of Basic Instinct.
Spare and poignantly bittersweet, Sarah Polley's wrenching romantic drama ... delves into the painful effects of Alzheimer's disease.
Dan Klores' documentary proves that truth really is stranger than fiction as it spins the tale of an infamous crime of passion--and its unbelievable result.
Despite strong performances from its excellent cast, Lajos Koltai's wistful adaptation of Susan Minot's novel doesn't quite connect.
Rowan Atkinson's second feature-length outing as the bumbling Brit has moments of genuine humor and charm, but overall, [it's] more of a mini-break than a full vacation
The movie looks gorgeous ... but the story never really builds momentum; you keep waiting for the 'real' action to start, but it never does.
Sure, global warming is scary, but chances are even Al Gore would be baffled by Larry Fessenden's moody, Arctic-set 'eco-thriller.'
Sean Penn's gorgeous, tragic film is both an advertisement for wanderlust and a sobering cautionary tale.
Orlando Bloom swaps swashbuckling swords and Elvish arrows for crimes of island passion in this murky, confusing thriller.
Fate plays havoc with a salesman's existence in [this] bleak psychological thriller about life and death in the New Mexico desert.
At times, Our Song feels like a documentary, never once seeming forced or far-fetched.
This Sixth Sense-wannabe is ultimately both predictable and as choked with cinematic cliches as Costner's resume is with post-apocalyptic epics.
Ultra-campy marionettes come to blah life in director Jonathan Frakes' souped-up but poorly written adaptation of the cult English sci-fi kids' show.
A pleasant, mostly realistic slice of life that puts Barrymore's trademark enthusiasm to good use.
High Heels' main problem is that Smith can't seem to decide whether the movie is an over-the-top comedy or a sassy action film.
As Leopold ... Jackman is the perfect mix of rogue and gentleman.
Tween star hits college; drinking, hazing ensue.
Suffers from a decided lack of creative storytelling.
What redeems the film is the cast, particularly the Ya-Yas themselves.
movie_title: Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood (2002)

movie_review_blurb: From the action to the characters to the humor, it's one of the brightest entries in this summer's family-movie showdown.
Engrossing and affecting, if ultimately not quite satisfying.
A formulaic romantic comedy that never quite makes up for in charm what it lacks in originality.
Strong performances by stars Ryan Gosling and Shareeka Epps elevate this gritty indie about an idealistic inner-city teacher who's crippled by drugs.
Matt Dillon gets gritty--and drinks a lot--in director Bent Hamer's interesting but uneven adaptation of Charles Bukowski's acclaimed novel.
Edward Norton and Evan Rachel Wood turn in strong lead performances, but their talent alone isn't enough to set David Jacobson's sun-bleached, modern-day Western on fire.
Amy Sedaris suits up as everyone's favorite former-prostitute/drug addict-turned-high school student in the long-awaited--and quite funny--big-screen version of the cult TV series.
You don't have to be an NPR junkie to appreciate Garrison Keillor and Robert Altman's sweet, gently funny tale about an old-fashioned radio show taking its last bow.
Woody Allen's London-set comedy caper doesn't break any new ground, but he and Match Point muse Scarlett Johansson are good for some odd-couple laughs.
While not quite as irresistibly seductive as its title character, Casanova is the perfect cinematic one-night stand: charming, romantic and awfully easy on the eyes.
Not even good sets, plenty of historical detail, and Billy Bob Thornton can put life into director John Lee Hancock's slow-moving, poorly acted Texan saga.
Stylish sci-fi director Guillermo Del Toro brings Mike Mignola's stone-fisted, horny (literally!) cult comic book hero to life in this wry, glossy adventure.
Sweet but unremarkable, First Daughter is never quite as cute as its star.
Alias superspy Jennifer Garner makes the most of her first starring role and discovers that love -- and navigating adult life -- really is a battlefield.
Faith takes a hip, raised-eyebrow beating in this biting yet surprisingly earnest dark comedy.
Versatile director Steven Soderbergh leaves the bright lights of Las Vegas far behind for this quiet, stark tale of friendship and murder in a small Midwestern town.
Ride along to dysfunction in quirky indie comedy.
The latest in a long line of 'quirky little English village' comedies is charming enough, but Keeping Mum doesn't break any new ground.
Thanks to grounded performances from its top-notch cast, Lars overcomes an ultra-quirky premise and develops into a thoughtful, albeit unusual, romance.
Charming, wordless, book-based holiday fable for all ages.
Charming '80s romantic comedy has innuendo, swearing.
Breezy, quirky romcom is predictable but sweet.
Imaginative adventure has lots of peril, nasty villain.
Tremendously heartwarming, positive docu for all ages.
Beautiful, original story about handling big feelings.
Docu underlines Saturday Night Live's cultural impact.
Outstanding role model urges kids to stand up to bullies.
movie_title: A Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Eye-opening drama about equality raises big questions.
Gentle family-friendly comedy has sweet messages.
Beautiful, emotional, intense story of faith and friendship.
Adventure is clever and engaging, despite animals in peril.
Clever, creative, action-packed adventure/toy ad.
Wrenching doc about underage sex trafficking, legal battles.
Animated comedy about sibling rivalry has peril, body humor.
Book-based adventure is fun ... if you like potty humor.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Thoughtful romantic dramedy has swearing, drinking, sex.
Diverse, entertaining reboot has some language, violence.
Moving dramedy serves up sexism, sexuality; lots of smoking.
Earnest, emotional book adaptation has strong messages.
Book-based teen romance has messages of empathy, diversity.
If Dharma and Greg went to therapy--a lot--you might end up with something like Robert Cary's appealing but uneven romantic comedy.
Fun, colorful adventure has some peril, lots of great music.
Provocative docu questions media's impact on girls' image.
Positive messages, but colorful adventure is mostly "meh."
'80s sci-fi adventure comedy has some drinking, swearing.
Quirky mix of laughs, romance, strong violence.
Simultaneously head-scratching and thought-provoking, Todd Haynes' metaphorical Bob Dylan drama feels more like poetry (or music) than a biopic.
Dustin Hoffman charms in [this] colorful fairy tale, but despite plenty of magical moments, it's missing the extra sparkle that could make it a classic.
Faithful to the bestselling novel on which it's based, The Kite Runner is a thoughtful, often heart-wrenching story about betrayal and redemption.
Thanks to earnest performances and flat-out amazing dancing, the fairly predictable inner-city drama of How She Move feels surprisingly fresh.
Starkly, brutally honest, Cristian Mungiu's well-acted abortion drama paints a bleak picture of Romanian life in the late '80s.
Teen-friendly romcom about love's ups and downs.
A charming mix of screwball comedy and poignant romance, Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day is lighthearted period fun.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Stuck somewhere between a dark comedy and a thriller, director Ira Sachs' Married Life doesn't really work as either, leaving its strong cast adrift.
For a movie about a diamond heist, Michael Radford's talky, 1960s-set Flawless lacks sparkle--despite strong period detail, earnest messages, and committed performances.
Wong Kar Wai's dreamy film boasts strong performances but ultimately feels more like a wistful character study than a heartfelt romance.
John Cusack takes it down several notches in James C. Strouse's somber, well-acted family mourning tale.
Candid, intimate, and often heart-wrenching, Nanette Burstein's documentary captures the confusion and agony of living through high school.
Book-based tropical adventure is good family fun.
Loving tribute to silent films has a few tense moments.
Comic book adventure mixes patriotism, explosive action.
Beloved book girl comes to life in sweet, kid-friendly tale.
Powerful documentary addresses critically important issue for kids.
The History Boys is much less about lighting and composition than it is about Bennett's sharp, insightful script.
Fast-paced fantasy has lots of tense moments.
Gavin Hood's Oscar-nominated tale about a young South African gangster who gets an unexpected chance at redemption is literally a world apart from anything produced by Hollywood.
Fun, fast-paced sequel is more upbeat than the original.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A lovely lyrical ode to high school misfits and the adults they grow into.
A buoyant and disarming drama about sons and fathers, death and dying, living and loving and all the ways we find ourselves starting over, hoping to finally get it right.
Between Bay's obsession to make his 3-D matter and the artistry of the special effects legions amassed for the project, the visual payoff is striking.
A frustrating mix of smart flash and smirking impudence.
The film, like the tour, will satisfy the Conan cravings of hardcore fans the most, and prove an enjoyable enough diversion for the rest.
What a relief in times saturated with news of the worst of humanity to see something of the best.
"Mr. Popper's Penguins," a mildly amusing flight of fancy for the family crowd, is far better for its penguins than its Popper.
Their travels and squabbles are great fun to watch, the countryside is bucolic, the food mouthwatering. You just wouldn't want to go on a real road trip with them.
An emotional runaway of a film that carries neither the insight nor the uplift to make the weight of its dark journey worth it.
Depp, back again as the swashbuckling miscreant who favors guy-liner and gold, somehow manages to keep this ship of fools afloat. But just barely.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Oh, what a headache-inducing, unapologetic money grab we have in "The Hangover Part II."
That expressiveness combined with the talented voice cast brings a nuance, a sense of reality that is hard to achieve in animation.

Not the first documentarian to examine Saint Laurent's life, this affectionate and frustrating film is essentially a deconstruction of the aesthetic life of this true visionary as defined by the art he collected.
No great epiphanies, just a few days, a little perspective, nicely told.
That rarest of treats: an R-rated romantic comedy from the Venus point of view.
A tearful, joyful, imperfect, yet nearly irresistible ode to the human spirit.
The film's title, "There Be Dragons," is lifted from the way ancient maps warned of dangers to be found within uncharted territory. Joffé should have paid heed.
Krasinski is, once again, the best thing about a romantic comedy.
Undone by a frustrating mire of multiple plots, overreaching special effects, leaden ancillary players and world-ending military standoffs that have all the tension of a water balloon fight.
Quirky, if uneven.
As so often happens with love, what you hope for is not even close to what you get, and in this case we are left with a heartbreaking disappointment of a film.
In "Dagenham," the filmmaker applies just the right pressure in examining why paying someone a fair wage, no matter their gender, shouldn't be all that difficult to agree to. Harrumph.
This little gem is all about the nature of chance encounters and how they can change us in unexpected ways.
movie_title: La tête en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There are no grand insights, but in all the fretting and frustration, the filmmaker cracks a window into the new Russian soul, albeit a tiny one.
For all the zaniness, the movie's understanding and insight come in moments so incisive that the sharpness will sting.

The kung fu itself is great fun to watch, from the discipline of balancing on one foot on a wooden pillar, the other in the air, for hours at a time to the confrontations that send fist and feet flying.
Allows room for a lot of thinking about other things - its cast most notably, since watching their struggle to move beyond the mundane is painful.
More amusing than you might expect, but probably not by much.
An ethereal and ephemeral musing on the art and artifice of communication.
Bristling with dangers both corporeal and cerebral, "The Debt" is a superbly crafted espionage thriller packed with Israeli-Nazi score settling.
Even with all their huffing and puffing, this very salty, often funny affair is never quite as satisfying as it should be.
I do hope that "Don't" doesn't do Nixey in, as he has a real knack for staging high anxiety. For Del Toro, the question is, what happened?
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The comedy isn't always as crisp as it should be, but Peretz has the perfect partner in crime in Rudd.
It's kind of a wicked blast to watch, especially if you're in the mood for some righteous revenge.
"FD 5" did not raise even a single goose bump - which for a movie that bills itself as horror is not a good thing.
Laughter, which is ladled on thick as gravy, proves to be the secret ingredient -- turning what should be a feel-bad movie about those troubled times into a heart-warming surprise.
Even Neil Patrick Harris, who has proved he can save just about any sinking ship (see prime-time awards shows such as the Emmys or Tonys), cannot make this boat float.

Carved out of cyber-reality and global in reach, this fast-paced documentary is shaped as much by Internet savvy as traditional filmmaking, which doesn't make the experience of it any less satisfying, or the implications any less provocative.
This grand romantic gesture about grand romantic gestures conjures up the bittersweet magic of first loves, lasting loves, lost loves and all the loves in between.
Director Mike Cahill has woven sci-fi imaginings and quantum physics theories of parallel universes into a provocative meditation on the prospect of rewriting your life history.
Is Saldana the new Schwarzenegger, only leaner, meaner and much better looking in spandex? I think so.

Who knew that the best place to put Vin Diesel would be between the Rock and a hard place? The spot has never been tighter, or righter, and the testosterone never higher than in the hot jacking action of "Fast Five."
There are times when the tension lags badly and the story loses its way as Umay spins between her worlds. Still, it's a worthy start, and Aladag's distinctive voice helps the film survive any dismay.
With a quiet restraint and an economy of movement in even the most brutal moments, Azabal makes the sometimes operatic extremes of Nawal's tribulations come to chilling life.
What makes this intriguing, yet woefully uneven film so relatable is that there is nothing about Ned's experience that seems extreme.

What the filmmakers have done so artfully is strip the story down to the bare essentials of the most significant loves of Barney's life and how his behavior, both good and bad, never stops rippling across that universe.
What "The Dilemma" ultimately does best is create a platform for Vaughn to drag that iconic character of his into full-blown adulthood.
[It] ultimately gives us a story of hope, and from Bardem, a performance of staggering depth, unquestionably one of the year's best.
An intensely intimate rendering of love that limits itself to that first falling in and that last falling out.
"Gulliver's Travels" is one of those movies that falls between complete disaster and loads of fun. Mild amusement is probably about right.

When the starting point is a world in which even the toughest guys wear their hearts on their sleeves, the trick for filmmakers is how to walk the line without getting stuck in the muck, and that is a problem the filmmaker hasn't yet figured out.
The sheer pleasure of the first film in 2000, already dimming by the time we got to "Meet the Fockers" four years later, has officially gone kaput.
Sadly, an obsession with raunchy one-liners trips everything up, turning a clever conceit into something closer to a sleazy, cheesy affair.
Though the film is peppered with one-liners tailor-made for Spacey to sling with stinging effect, it doesn't so much leave you laughing as just weary, and wishing this weren't a true story at all.
This is a story of few words, a lot of great music and countless emotional shadings.
movie_title: Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Oh, there are sword fights aplenty (as bloodless as ever), but instead of a real story, we are left clinging to individual moments.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Gosling is given the barest blueprint of a life gone terribly wrong and the actor struggles to make something out of nothing, though he does manage to give the older David an aura of weirdness that is downright creepy.

Though Carrey seems to be giving his heart to Steven's romance with Phillip, and pouring a lot of sweat equity into very vigorous sex, he never gets beyond his Jim Carrey-ness to let us discover the character.
"Burlesque" is top-heavy from start to finish. Maybe that's what you do when you have nothing new to say.
Finally, after years of suffering through Hollywood's predictable pap, sentimental mush, boring bromances and mean girl clichés, comes a love story that is actually worth falling for...

Haggis seems obsessed with making sure we "get it" in every scene. You can almost feel the hammer poised right above your head to pound the point home. Beyond that, the film is too long on exposition in some places, too short in others, never just right.
Having such a complicated man as a central character is a blessing and a curse for the filmmakers, and the movie struggles because of this.

New players, a new story line, a new director and nearly three decades of improved technology including all the whiz-bang-wow the latest 3-D has to offer. Unfortunately, there's not nearly enough new life.
With "The Greatest Movie Ever Sold" Spurlock creates a good time along with some surprisingly salient observations as he tries to keep his balance on this very slippery slope.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: If you're a Sandler film buff, the comedy is classic Sandler and will probably satisfy. Still, the best thing about the movie remains Aniston - she is reason enough to just go with it.

"I Am Number Four," the appealing new kid-on-the-teen-angst block, reverberates with much of the same dark combustible mix of action and romance that's been fueling the "Twilight" vampire mega-franchise for a while now.
Reichardt has stripped "Meek's" down to bare essentials and careful emotions. The cast captures that quality beautifully - like the water that is running out, everything is conserved.
"My Perestroika" reminds us that no matter how repressive a government, no matter how entrenched attitudes may seem, underneath the surface there are countless individuals very much like us.
More things work than not in this sweetened sweet bird of youth. Maybe the G is for good fun or great music or a gentle good time.
"Scream 4" finds a way to live up to its gory past while it carves out new terrors in new ways (new media helps).
[Green] has an easy touch when it comes to comedy, which means you can almost sense those moments when the actors give themselves over to the silliness.
Paper and possibilities do not a movie make. I'm guessing even Christopher Cross is cross.
A wonderfully wild provocation - an imperfect, overlong, intemperate and utterly absorbing romp through the id that I wouldn't have missed for the world.
While Furman shows a mostly steady hand with his actors, the narrative flow trips things up considerably. Connelly's book turns out to be too much for screenwriter John Romano to handle.

Though the comedy in "Cedar Rapids" is Arteta's broadest yet, the film reflects the care he takes with his cast, the sort that helped reveal an acting depth no one suspected from Jennifer Aniston in 2002's "The Good Girl."
After the sharp bite and harsh light of most American-style guy-based funny films today, "Paul" comes as such sweet relief.
You can't help but wish there had been a lot more heart in this Marine's story.
Instead of breathing life into cartoonist Berkeley Breathed's cheeky kids morality tale, the movie - with all its 3-D motion capture animation flash - flatlines.
Gorgeously shot, smartly conceived, cleverly cast, badly executed -- the lush medieval beauty here is at best only skin deep.
Dolan is proving to be adept at and unafraid of teasing out the flaws of his characters, seemingly more concerned with whether they are interesting than whether an audience will like them.
Overall "Take Me Home Tonight" represents a lateral move at best for its 24-hour party people, a step back at worst, and not worth your time either way.
In a world choked with animated films -- the good, the bad and the ugly -- it's hard to be either original or great. Yet director Gore Verbinski has done both -- and without 3-D...
Anderson spends most of his energy creating a mood - making "Vanishing" more cerebral than white-knuckle, though a few more shrieks (mine) might have been nice.
Mildly amusing or marginally offensive is about as good as it gets.
The disappointment is that for all of the possibilities, "Limitless" never gets beyond "limited."
The barbs feel stale at best, squandered at worst, and the ominous music that accompanies each sounds as if it has been lifted from the silent movie era.
[It] might as well be called "Simply Irresistible," because thanks to the mischievous monkeyshines of a baby chimp named Oscar, it comes pretty close.
Lonergan has created a forceful yet extremely fitful film that teases with moments of brilliance only to frustrate in the end.
Mostly "Lockout" is lost in space.
All the actors do a decent job with whatever is thrown at them -- usually sharp objects.
A wonderfully human and humane story about one of those lost-and-found children who tend to slip through society's not-so-safe safety nets.
Miller and Lord clearly understand the push-and-pull and hyper-competitiveness that make guy friendships both complex and stupid.
Segel ... seems to be staking his claim on just about any sweet, clueless character that comes along. He should be more discriminating.
A buttery rich animated tale of love, jazz, showbiz, fame and politics in the late '40s and early '50s that is as catchy as its tunes.
It starts with a great story - of love and politics, time travel and mystical pathways between planets - badly sucked dry.
Starkly beautiful and exceedingly demanding, "The Turin Horse," which Hungarian master Béla Tarr has said will be his last film, is both easy and impossible to define.
There is an appealing nyuk, nyuk nostalgic spirit to"The Three Stooges."
For all its good intentions and talented performers and filmmakers, "Being Flynn" leaves you feeling as if everyone is trying a little too hard. Sometimes, less really is more.
More a story of whispers when cries are what's called for with lives, livelihoods and family honor on the line.
There is some sinister fun to be had in watching Kinnear skating toward disaster on ice that is very thin indeed.

If you can get past the gross invasion of privacy issues that would exist if this were real life and not just a frothy confection, what you have is some bittersweet fun peppered by bursts of sharp patter, the best between the boys.
This is a movie that leaves you wanting more. To care more, to cry more, to love more.

Packed with details that somehow don't weigh it down, this is a hopeful film - about the power of honest work to confer dignity as well as put food on the table, about how the seed of an idea can take root and grow.
movie_title: Bonsai People: The Vision of Muhammad Yunus (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This mind-and-fork-bending sci-fi saga comes from the freaky imaginations of director Josh Trank and screenwriter Max Landis, who've packed their feature debut with smartness.
The camera is unflinching, and so is Wheatley, as the story moves toward the unthinkable. It's left to you when and whether to look away.
A vibrant and heartfelt French film that captures the mood and the memories of young parents who found themselves in the trenches fighting for the life of their child.
Wain has always brought a kind of zany sensibility to his films, but he has never seemed more confident coloring outside the lines.

The Sparks-styled romance has almost become its own movie genre - predictable, pure of heart, sentimental and never straying from the boy-meets-girl basics, or the surface, for that matter - and in that "The Lucky One" delivers.
Like Freeway, the lovable stray dog at the center of this very teary comedy, "Darling Companion"has lost its way.

By bringing in a diverse group of big thinkers to take part in a very animated, sometimes agitated, discussion, the filmmaker has succeeded in bringing what could have been a very dry mountain of data, theories and experimental research to vibrant life.
It's not "On Golden Pond" by any stretch, but it is nice to have Fonda back in the fractious family way.
Gerwig is ... distinctive and interesting an actress to watch, especially when the story includes a lot of raw truth-telling.

A neon-saturated, high-flying trapeze act with enough frenetic funny business that it's a wonder the folks behind this zillion-dollar franchise about zoo critters on the lam didn't send the animals to the circus sooner.

It is an absolute wonder to watch and creates a warrior princess for the ages. But what this revisionist fairy tale does not give us is a passionate love - its kisses are as chaste as the snow is white.
There are wild chases and fever dreams, and sometimes the thieving and the thieves become a muddle. But the animation of A Cat in Paris itself is so artful, it steals the day.
"Men in Black 3" has got the MIB mojo back - well, most of it anyway.
In this tale about growing up and falling in love, it seems Anderson has found his true heart.
In Harris' hands, Linda is guileless but believable, her smile so worn and wary that it almost hurts to see it.
Cute couple Kendrick and Crawford are completely lost at sea. But the guys in the Dudes Group have the worst of it - they are a whiny, unappealing bunch through and through.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: By turns hysterical, heretical, guilty, innocent, silly, sophisticated, teasing and tedious.
A tale of heart-wrenching tragedy and uplifting triumph that never quite hits its stride.
This funny, sick twist of social satire is certainly locked and loaded, even if its aim is sometimes off.
The affection between the musicians and Simon is clear. The portrait that emerges time and again is personal and a reflection of the realities of apartheid.
There is a lot of hope in the air in "I Wish," but the film never feels sappy.
The film's single saving grace is Turner, who channels that legendary Catholic guilt like there is no tomorrow.
It all makes for a movie whose infectious charm outweighs some of the predictability that slips in around the edges.
It's neither grand nor grisly enough to seriously satisfy Poe-ish cravings for murder, mystery and literary allusions.
A true-life Texas tale so perfectly told it seems more like eavesdropping than moviegoing.
A little restraint would have gone a long way to making this a far funnier, fleeter affair.
Oh, that the actual human dynamics of the unfolding story could have been as dramatic, as on the edge as that ledge.
A not very good romantic comedy made somewhat bearable by Faris.
There is a larger message to be found here, but it never derails the taut vintage thriller that's been constructed.
Watching Carano kick, spin, flip, choke, crack and crush the fiercest of foes - mostly men about twice her size - is thoroughly entertaining, highly amusing and frankly somewhat awe-inspiring.
A tragedy infused with comedy [that] calls for a balancing act from filmmaker and star alike, a tightrope they navigate with nary a wobble.
In trying to take a bite out of crime and another out of fame, [Monahan has] ended up with more than he can chew for his first time in the director's chair.
Where are the gods of Olympus when you need them? I ask on behalf of "Immortals," because mere mortals were apparently not able to create a movie that actually made sense.
What is missing is something new - clarity, insight, outrage. Instead, its understatement is ultimately its undoing.
It is a lighter Von Trier, a lovely Von Trier, a seriously romantic Von Trier that emerges from "Melancholia," and I quite hope he stays around.

"Tower Heist" might not be a classic (it's not), but at least for a little while it will make you laugh instead of cry about the current state of affairs, which is more than you can say about a lot of things.
In every move, Depp makes you believe this was a passion project for the actor, one he dedicates to Thompson.
It's Shakespeare as B-movie, if you will, or to borrow from the bard, a boffo blast, which I'm pretty sure is from either "King Lear" or "Hamlet."
It breaks my heart to tell you that "Breaking Dawn" is broken.
If only the ticking clock were more tightly wound; if only more time were used to develop the romance and relationships; if only dying didn't seem so easy.
Sometimes the facts can get in the way of the drama, and that's the central problem here.
What writer-director Sean Durkin has given us is an existential thriller about identity and just how tenuous a grasp we have on who we really are.
Like the Texas City killer's plans, something's gone terribly wrong.
There is some harmless pleasure to be found when feathers aren't ruffled, when the fowl is not foul.
"Fireflies" is probably too convoluted to pave the way for more roles of this sort, but watching Reynolds get inside Michael's pain, you hope it won't be long until something will.
It's an accomplished piece of filmmaking from the trio, who are making their feature-length documentary debut.
If nothing else, the film reminds just how arresting an actor Shepard can be. Like Blackthorn, he's only gotten better with age.

Neither as bad as it sounds nor quite as good as it could be, although the 9-year-old bruiser next to me pummeled the armrest, spilled his soda and screamed "awesome" through every one of the fight scenes.

For first-time screenwriter Wingate and Segal, in only his second feature (2004's "The Last Run), it's impressive work - they never overplay the pity card, opting for insight into the complexities of growing up instead.
For all of difficulties, there is an authenticity in Levinson's work that you can see in the film, and his is a compelling voice playing in that minor key.
It is the kind of film that leaves you limp, exhausted and feeling battered by the end. But its wrenching performances make the beating worth weathering.
There are a few stumbles, but not too many, and by the time Gary and Walter get to a showstopping number that asks the burning question - "Am I a man, or a Muppet?" - you are completely hooked.
This very gritty bit of greased action does a decent job of shaking the sluggish out of January.
A film that while quite personal in its storytelling comes without the rigor or the power of an independent filmmaking voice.
An affecting if not always satisfying portrait of the strong-willed leader humbled by age.
Oduye as Alike is "Pariah's" subtle center, with the actress moving seamlessly between the tomboy thrilled to play hoops with her dad to the sour-faced daughter forced to wear pink by her mom.

A film filled with both sentiment and substance.

The beauty and ugliness of "Desert Riders" will haunt you. The boys and the world Sarin takes us into linger long after the final frame.

"Belle" is greatly buoyed by Mbatha-Raw's performance. She infuses Dido with a confident and intelligent grace that keeps you engaged long after the tangled story has let both the actress and audience down.
This modest indie with major ambitions is directed by veteran cinematographer Steven Bernstein, making a solid feature debut.
The bond between Spidey and the fearful and fleeing masses, which should be emotional and strong, has lost its personal touch.
My advice to guys? Step away from the vehicle, because "The Other Woman" is out of control and intent on running down a certain kind of male.
"Blue Ruin" is an uneven film, and there are slip-ups along the way, but the tension that settles in slowly like a low-grade fever keeps you with it.
This raunchy unrooting of a settled suburban idyll exposes the considerable angst of emerging adulthood with a kind of scatological fervor designed to elicit oodles of inappropriate laughs.
Artful, insightful and at times very, very funny, much of its wry humor is due to Allen, who co-stars opposite Turturro.
An extraordinary new drama whose fierceness, like its 6-year-old heroine Hushpuppy, grabs on and won't let go.
It's a rip-roaring ride.
You come for the conversation, and in that, "The Trip to Italy" rarely disappoints.
All in all, "Happy Christmas" is a good deal like cartoon Charlie Brown's classic tree - scraggly, plenty of heart and much to enjoy, especially if you prefer your presents homemade.
As to whether "Moonlight" is magical - it is, but ever, ever so slightly.

Fernandez is astute in the way he fills the empty hours on screen. He sets a slow steady rhythm and embraces lingering shots and long silences to catch the way the days are lazy about unfolding, especially for Sebastian.
There are occasional flashes of the exceptional, but the film's dodgy story can't sustain them.
Since it's a comedy, much could be forgiven if the film was consistent in generating laughs, but the comedy is as erratic as the couple's sex life.
Make no mistake, a good "Purge" does not equal a good movie, but the post-apocalyptic thriller is slightly more interesting because it takes itself, and its menace, more seriously.
Joe Berlinger's densely detailed new documentary about the legendary Boston mobster is disturbing on so many levels it's hard not to wonder why Bulger was the only one on trial.
movie_title: Whitey: United States of America v. James J. Bulger (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This sequel's spoof of its predecessor's riff on the original 1980s-era buddy-cop TV show coalesces into a raucous, raunchy, irreverent, imperfect riot.
An extraordinarily intimate portrait of a life unfolding and an exceptional, unconventional film in which not much else occurs. Never has so little meant more.
Casting Marion-Rivard in the title role was a risk that paid off, giving the film its authenticity, also its imperfections, which are easy enough to live with.
"Venus in Fur," a whip-smart dissection of gender politics via some teasing S&M, is arch. So arch in fact that it is surprising it's a Roman Polanski film.
There are some laughs and, at least on screen, more than a few tears. But it doesn't come together with the kind of satisfying punch a comedy should deliver.
In "Snowpiercer," Bong's first English-language film, nothing gets lost in translation.
It's still not a great movie, but it is, most definitely, full-metal Bay.
"Third Person" maddens far more than it intrigues. Indeed, more curious than anything about the movie itself is how such an artistic stumble happened.
"The Moment" is a psychological thriller more muddled than the mind and the maze it is caught up in.
Hart hits such adrenaline-fueled extremes it's exhausting.

But don't be misled by its simple premise. "Land Ho!" is full of surprises, rich in the way it noses around the rocky terrain of aging in an indifferent world through the engaging performances of its two stars.
Don't let the title of this indie gem fool you, "Small Time" has humor and heart big time.
Rather than sifting through the emotional layers of a surprisingly determined young woman, more often the scenes feel drained of life.

French filmmaker Alain Guiraudie's tantalizingly erotic fable of love, passion and death.
What "Awkward" is actually about, albeit unintentionally, is how passing off misogyny for comedy has gotten so terribly passé, as insulting to the guys as to the young women.

Chilean director Sebastian Lelio's near-perfect film about the very imperfect world of a divorced woman of a certain age.
Filled with very good intentions, very bad dialogue and a surprisingly affecting turn by its star Vanessa Hudgens.

What makes "Lone Survivor" work as well as it does are the human exchanges. Whether friend or foe, the moments feel all too real.
"The Lego Movie" is a massive collision of subversive humor, hyper-kinetic energy, mind-jangling design, spinning colors and about 15 million Legos, no exaggeration.
Man, does this movie have a savage bite.
Peter Jackson's newest installment of the Tolkien trilogy is set afire by the scorching roar of a dragon.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating new documentary about art, obsessions, ideas and answers.
The most hopeful - and the best - of this solid and unsettling series.

These Birds Walk serves as a reminder of the resilience of children and how little it takes to keep hope alive.

There is a brashness in the risks taken, the very imperfections revealing an artist finding new inspiration. For Lee, this weird, brutal film seems to have freed him.

No matter what the title says, there is no welcome waiting for you.

Wonderfully animated and well-voiced, "Rio 2" is nevertheless too much. Too much plot, too many issues, too many characters.

Watching this film feels like a genesis moment - of sci-fi fable, of filmmaking, of performance - with all the ambiguity and excitement that implies.

Almost every line is delivered with such overwrought bombast, just inches at times from the camera, you may feel a need to dodge the spittle.
As you might guess, this is not a film for everyone's taste. But for fans of the martial arts genre, Evans has created a scintillating, if sometimes imperfect, new chapter.

movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: What "I'll See You" does particularly well is get at how any relationship - whatever your age - comes with a limited, rather than a lifetime, warranty.

movie_review_blurb: So bad you'd think it was directed by the worst sort of male chauvinist director.
